meaning: 1. introductory exclamation like English Oh or Well. 2. miki-a ‘to say “ah”’. 3. grammatical functor marking attribution.
the abaca plant, fiber, or cloth.
(V.) mayabak, mayayabak, meyabak; to do something until morning; become morning. (N.) morning.
(V.) bother, worry. [usually distributive: mangabala’, as in: e ka mangabala. ‘Don’t worry’].
(V.) makiyabe ‘accompany’; mi-abeyabe ‘live together, stay together’, (N.) friend, companion [used as a term of address], kayabe ‘companion’; pa:makiya’be ‘the skill of making and keeping friends’.
(V.) -an: ‘to warn someone’; ma-‘to be warned’; payabi’su ‘have someone warned’; i-‘take something as a warning’. (N.) warning; subpoena; ma:nabi’su ‘one who warns’.

(V.) -an ‘to return something’; imitate. maki- -an ‘to answer back, retort’, mablas, minablas, paki-qablas, payablasan, inablas, ayablas, makayablas, meyablas, pamanablas, pekaqablas. (N.) what one gives in return for something else. echo; revenge. kakablas ‘echo’.
(V.) man- ‘to fertilize’; pa-‘have something fertilized’; maki-, paki-‘share fertilizer’.
(V.) in–an, mi–an ‘be swarmed on by tiny insects called absang’, (N.) gnat, fruitfly (?)–a very small insect.
(V.) magpaka-‘eat one’s fill’. See qabsiq. (D.) satisfied (with respect to hunger).
(V.) man-‘become ash’; mi–an ‘get ashes on self’; -an [abwan] ‘scour (using ash)’. (N.) ashes.
(V.) pag–an ‘submit something to lawyers’. magqabugadu, see qabugadu. (N.) lawyer.
(V.) -an [abuluran] ‘to de-rib (to remove the center rib from a leaf)’, ‘to put a crease in’.
(V.) man-, pa-‘abuse, take unfair advantage’. (D.) ma-. (N.) one who takes unfair advantage; ka- -an, kapana-.
(V.) ‘reach’, ‘hand something to someone’. ‘understand’: E ku pa ayabutan. ‘I can’t grasp the meaning yet’.
(N.) milled rice. maga:qabyas ‘rice dealer’ [bigasera–from Tagalog, is also used].
(V.) -an ‘to put something on a spit’; pa- ‘to have something spitted’. (D.) ma-‘to be spitted’. (N.) a spit, made of bamboo, for barbecuing.
(N.) explosion. pa:pakbu’ng ‘a toy gun or bamboo piston device used to make fruit seeds shoot out–like a pop-gun; or a nail-and-tube device for exploding caps’.
(V.) manga-[distributive] have an accident. (D.) mayaksidenti ‘be hurt in an accident’.
(V.) -an ‘to grate, scrape’. (N.) adjaran-ungut ‘coconut-grating stool’; see kudkuran. pipagadjaran ‘place for scraping’.
(V.) mang- ‘pray’ (intransitive). pa:ng- ‘pray for something’; maki-‘pray together’; pakipang- ‘pray together for…’.
(V.) pangaladwan ‘do something a second time’. (Nu.) two. kakadwaq ‘second’; pangalawaq ‘the second one (e.g. child)’.
(V.) summon, invite, signal. man-, -an, pa-, pan-. (D.) may-‘be invited’. (N.) pa:managkat ‘manner of inviting’.
(N.) spider web. (D.) mayagiq ‘be full of cobwebs’. (V.) man- ‘to remove cobwebs’; pa-‘have cobwebs removed’.
(V.) harvest, gather. ma:magtal, agtala’n, papayagtal, manayagtal. (N.) pa:nagtal ‘the harvest’; pi:panagtala’n ‘place of harvest’.
(N.) accident. (V.) manga-[distributive] ‘have an accident’. (D.) mayaksidenti ‘be hurt in an accident’.
(V.) associate. maki-a’gum ‘join a group’, (N.) a:gu’man ‘an association’. kagum ‘associate, a concomitant’.
(N.) current. (V.) mamagus, minagus ‘flow’. papa-agus-an ‘cause to flow’.
sina’da (N.) a medicinal liquid used to clean wounds.
(N.) cold sore. (V.) [stative] miyagyapan ‘have cold sore’; [stat. distributive] manga-agyap-an.
(Neg.) none. (V.) manga-‘lose things [distributive]’; a:walaq ‘be lost unintentionally’; ma:walaq ‘be lost’; maki-qalaq; makiqala:ala’q ‘go along in denying’; payalaq ‘deny, denounce’.

(N.) ala’lan ‘election’, pa:manala’l ‘manner of electing’; pipagalalan ‘polling place’. (V.) man-. mangayalal ‘elect repeatedly’; papa-yalal ‘get someone elected’; ke:ala’l ‘cause election’. (D.) mayalal ‘be elected’.
(N.) ala’le ‘care’. alalayan ‘a prop, support’. (V.) alalayan ‘support, maintain something’; magkala:kalale ‘beware of’. (D.) malale ‘careful (e.g. speech)’.
(N.) wire. ala’mbring suksukan ‘barbed wire’. (D.) mayalambre ‘be caught on a wire’.
(N.) palate, roof of mouth. see telabanwa.
1. in combination with numbers, as alas singko ‘five o’clock’. 2. bungang ala’s ‘heat-rash’. 3. ala’s ‘ace (in card-playing)’.
(N.) flood. maki-a’lbug. (V.) mangayalbugan’be ‘flooded regularly’. payalbug, payalbugan, ka-albug.
(N.) place where the sun sets. (St.) mi-albug-an ‘be caught by nightfall’.
(N., V.) noise, make noise; see qalburutu.
(N.) sun; day. ganing-aldo ‘pre-dawn morning’, kayaldawanan ‘birthday; anniversary’. (D.) aldo-aldo ‘daily’.
(N.) dust. (D.) maqalikabuk ‘dusty’; mi:alika-buka’n ‘covered with dust’; makaqa-likabuk [St.] ‘dusty’. (V.) ma:n-alikabuk ‘raising dust’.

(N.) example. pa:manalimbawaq ‘giving of examples’; pipagalimbawan ‘thing used for an example’; pekaqalimbawaq ‘the best example’. (V.) man-alimbawaq ‘give an example’; papayalimbawaq ‘make into an example’; pakiqalimbawaq.
(N.) mole. pekaqalimpuyuq ‘imitation mole’. (V.) man-alimpuyuq ‘put on a fake mole. (D.) alimpuyuwan ‘full of moles’.
(N.) athletes’ foot. (D.) maqalipungan ‘suffering from athletes’ foot’; makayalipungaq ‘conducive to a.f.’.
(N.) a person who acts skillfully, lively. pangaqalistu ‘acting skillfully’. (D.) kaqalistuwan; kasingalistu; pekaqalistu.

(N./D.) other. pami-aliwaq ‘difference’; pamanaliwaq ‘process of change’. (D.) maqaliwa:liwaq ‘all sorts of’; miyayaliwaq ‘disparate’; mi-aliwaq ‘different’. (V.) man-aliwaq ‘change something’; i-aliwaq ‘change something’.
(N.) thunder; (?lightning?); see duldul. Usually this word is used in curses, as: dipaning alti!
(N.) 1. eaves and drain of a roof; [metaphorically] ‘heavy drinking’. 2. shins. (D.) meyalulud ‘barked shins’.
(N.) aluminum; cheap money (new coins–as contrasted to the older coins with more silver content).
(N.) wave. (D.) alunqalun ‘roller-coaster motion’; ‘wavy (hair)’, miyayalunan ‘be immersed in a wave’.
(N.) contribution. peka-ambag ‘thing given’. (V.) [intransitive] man-ambag, pan-ambag, makapanambag. [transitive] i-ambag, ayambag, ayam-bagan, panambaga, ka-ambagan, pa-ambag, apayambagan.
(N.) dew. (V.) mamambun ‘be about to rain’. (D.) mayambun ‘overcast, misty’; miyambunan ‘covered with dew’.
(V.) mamambus ‘share (food)’. -andam- (V.) borrow; see -dam-. manamdam, mangayamdam, pakiyamdam, makiyamdam, makayamdam.
(N.) winter, the cold season from October to January.
(N.) mosquito. (V.) amuk-an ‘be bitten by mosquitoes’. (D.) mayamuk ‘be full of mosquitoes (place)’.
(N.) a kind of grass or weed with pronged seeds.

(N.) child; (pl.) a:nak. anak-anakan ‘adopted child’; ina:yinak ‘godchildren’; pekayanak ‘substitute for a child’; anak-bastardo, anak-banggera, anak-puta, anak-lele-kwayan, anak-lalam-tete ‘illegitimate child’, (V.) mang-anak ‘give birth’, maka-anak ‘capable of giving birth’.
(N.) serrated edges (of cloth). Simon de Andas, a famous Spaniard who once transferred the seat of Spanish government to Bacolor.
(N.) female sexual organs. a’ntak-ne-da-mu [an indecent curse]. (D.) mayantak ‘sexually attractive (female)’.
(N.) anti-ra’bis, anti-te-tanus ‘injections to prevent rabies, tetanus’.

(Subcombiner) later, and then, so. [often combined with uling, as: anyaq, e ko bisang mamangan king kekami uling ing asan mi tuyuq. ‘And so that’s why you don’t want to eat at our house because our main course is dried fish’].
(Prep.) up to, until. (N.) angganan ‘boundary’. (V.) man-angga ‘reach as far as, journey to’; mipa-angga; mangayang-ganan.
(N.) mist, spray, blowing rain. (V.) mamanggiq ‘it is raining and blowing’.
(N.) wind. (V.) mamangin ‘the wind is blowing’; angin-an, in-angin ‘held in the wind’; payangin, magpayangin, magpakayangin. (D.) mayangin ‘windy (season, people)’.
(V.) invite. (N.) anyahan ‘invitation’. -anya’yaq (V.) mang-anya’yaq ‘get inflamed (of a wound)’.
(N.) narra, a kind of tree. Apalit, a town in Pampanga.
(N.) a vegetable, ampalaya. [metaphorically] a person with a sour disposition.
(N.) bait. (V.) apan-an ‘bait something’; man-apan ‘put out bait’; maipanapan ‘bait each other’; pan-apan-an.
(N.) lime (calcium oxide); used in making cement; and as a component of the betel-chew.
(N.) fire, flame, spark. (V.) mamapi’q ‘is sparking, is on fire’.
(N.) beach [probably a recent borrowing; more commonly: bebe-dagat].
(N.) a kind of fish, expensive and considered quite a delicacy.

(N.) grandparent, especially grandmother. As a term of address, apu is used for grandfather and grandmother; as a term of reference, usually it is restricted to grandmother, with ingkong being used for grandfather. With saints’ names, as: Apu Lusya ‘Saint Lucy’.
See na:pun ‘yesterday’; gatpanapun ‘afternoon’; patinga’pun ‘the whole day’.
(N/V/St.) imitation, similarity. Apus mu ku kaya. ‘You are making me look like him’. pa:yapus; see -kyapus.
(V.) mag-aral ‘study, go to school’. manig-aral [distributive]; papag-aral ‘be sent to school’. (N.) panig-aral-an; pag-aral-an ‘lesson’.
(N.) arap/arapa’n ‘the front’. (D.) maka-arap; miaraparap ‘be situated in front’.
(N.) things customarily disapproved; statements of customary disapproval.
(N.) 1. fish. 2. viand, i.e., food eaten with rice. (V.) asan-an, in-asan, as: nanung inasan yu? ‘What did you eat with your rice?’.
(N.) gills. asa’q- (V.) asa-an ‘put hope in someone’.

(N.) spouse; [metaphor] ‘one of a pair, like mortar and pestle’, tala-asawa ‘a married person’. (V.) mag-asawa ‘get married’; mang-asawa ‘[old] arrange marriage’, ‘[new] have sexual intercourse’; paki-asawa ‘have someone married to someone else’; pang-asawa-n ‘rape someone’; mi-asawa ‘be married’.
(N.) salt; [metaphor] ‘brains, cleverness’. (V.) asin-an ‘to salt something’. payasin, paki-asinan, man-asin, apa-yasin, ayasinan ‘unintentionally salted’.
(N.) light from a heavenly body; see saslag.
(N.) place where the sun rises, east.
(N.) vinegar. (D.) maslam ‘sour’. (V.) aslam-an ‘add vinegar to something’; pan-aslam ‘use something to sour’.
(N.) crack. (St.) mispak, mangaspak, mayayaspak ‘cracked’; apayaspak. (V.) panaspakan.
(N.) stake. (V.) man-astaka ‘place stakes’; astak-an ‘bound with stakes’.
(N.) blue. (D.) ma-asul ‘dark blue’; ma-asulasul ‘light blue’; maka-asul ‘wearing blue clothes’.
(N.) a frightening spirit creature, half-human, half-bird, vampire-like, said to prey on corpses and unborn children. (V.) aswang-an, inaswangan ‘made victim by an aswang’.
(N.) 1. comb. 2. harrow. (V.) man-aswe ‘use a harrow. aswe-n ‘comb (hair)‘; payaswe ‘have hair combed by another’.
(Cocombiner) ‘and’. Sometimes ‘that’, as: kapna mu at bala mu ‘it’s good that you know it’.
(V.) escort away from home to another place. mamatad, i (h) atad, paki-atad. (N.) pamatad-oras ‘pastime’.
(N.) attack, heart-attack, stroke. (D.) me-atake ‘victimized by stroke’.
(Exist.) there is/there are, be. (N.) kayatina’n ‘wealth’. (D.) mikayatin ‘be wealthy’.
1. Feast of Three Kings; 2. a constellation.
(V.) throw; itca ‘threw’. makayatcaq [ability]; atca-nan ‘throw something to somebody’; mipayatca; ayatca. (N). pa:manatcaq ‘pitching style’; piyatcanan ‘place something was thrown’.
(V.) to the back, rear; retrogress. see qatras.
(N.) older sister. Also used as a term of polite address to women, as: Atsing Edad, Atsing Son.
(N.) peak of a roof. (V.) manatap, atapan, payatap, panatap, paki-atap, ayatapan ‘to put on a roof’.
(N.) flatulence. (V.) atutan ‘affect another with one’s flatulence’.
(N.) a large bird of prey, crow or hawk.
(V.) ask for; see inyad. manyawad, menyad/ menyawad, inyawad/inawad, pakiqawad, pa:yawad, papan-yawad, pa:nyawaran, a:yawad, a:yan-yawad. (N.) pa:manyawad, piyawaran. (D.) mayawad, meyawad.
(D.) similar in appearance; see qawigqawig. miyayawig, makayawig.
(N.) air. (D.) de-ayri ‘works by means of air’.
(V.) agree with, go along with. ayun-an, pa-ayun-an, maki-ayun.
low place, underneath; old name of the town now called Lubao.
pig. babing-diku’t ‘wild pig’. (D.) bina’biq ‘careless’. (V.) mag-binabiq ‘be careless, act like a pig’.
get dressed; see piblas. mi-bablas ‘be dressed’; pi-bablas-an ‘dress someone else’.
up, upstairs, above. (V.) mag-babo, magpababo ‘go up’; papababo ‘put something on top’; makapagpababo ‘able to go on top’.
packed lunch, food carried along when on a trip. (V.) mag-baka’l ‘carry one’s lunch’; abakalan ‘able to carry something’.
mark, sign, indication. (V.) babakas, mamakas ‘make marks’; bakasan, bekasan ‘mark something’; pabakas ‘have something marked’.
scar, scab, peeling skin. (V.) mangabakbak, magpabakbak, mipamakbak ‘peel off something’. (D.) mabakbak.
yoke. makabakle ‘warp, or woof, in weaving’. (V.) bakle, bikle ‘put something across something else’. (D.) makabakle ‘out of condition, in a bad mood’.
mangrove wood (used for firewood); baka’wan mangroves ‘where wood is collected for charcoal’.
oar, paddle. (V.) babakse, mamakse ‘row, paddle’, makapamakse ‘be able to paddle’; makibakse ‘paddle with others’.
fence. (V.) mag-bakud, magpabakud ‘put up a fence’; bakur-an ‘fence something in’.
Bacolor, a town in Pampanga. makabakulud ‘plain, plateau, high level rocky place’.
(V.) mag-bakwe’ ‘smoke with burning part of cigarette or cigar inside mouth’; babakwe.
(N.) pulp, the part of the sugarcane which is discarded after milling; sawdust.
(D.) matching, compatible. (V.) bagay-an ‘match something to something else’. (N.) thing, object, affair. bage-ba’ge ‘small things, details’.
(N.) railroad car. bagune’ru ‘conductor’. (V.) pa:bagun ‘use a railroad car to carry’.
(N.) draw, a chance or turn. (V.) bagut-an ‘withdraw something, pull something out’. begutan, magpabagut, makibagut, mi-pamagut, mangabagut, pamagut. (D.) mabagut ‘withdrawn’; makabagut.
(N.) tropical storm, typhoon. pabagyu ‘a showoff’. (V.) babagyu ‘a typhoon is blowing’.
(Excl.) Of course!, That’s how it is!, Well, what else?!
(Excl.) Of course!, That’s how it is!, Well, what else?!
(N.) bachelor, unmarried male [also used of young male carabao]. mamayintau ‘one who is being a bachelor.

(N.) responsibility, warning, matter, concern as: ika ing ba:laq ‘you are in charge, it’s up to you, you decide’. e ba:laq ‘it doesn’t matter. (V.) bala-an, babalan, bebalan ‘warn someone about something’; paba:laq ‘give one responsibility’; panibalaq. (N.) kapama:lan ‘the government’.
[idiomatic expression–inflection highly limited]. bala’ mu ‘you would think; it seems; apparently’. bala’ ku ‘I think so; it seems so to me’.
(V.) bala’ba:n ‘cut something down’. be:la’baq, mamalabaq, pabalabaq, pamalaban.

(V.) magpabala’g ‘drop out’; maka-bala’g ‘fall accidentally’; manga-bala’g ‘dropping repeatedly’; pa:-balag ‘caused to drop’; a:balag ‘dropped’; a:pabala’g ‘had an abortion, miscarriage’. (D.) ma-balag ‘dropped’.
(N.) father of a married child as he stands related to the father of his child’s spouse. mibalai ‘be related as balai’. (V.) mamalai ‘arrange a marriage’; abalai ‘be made balai of someone’.
(N.) a kind of insect said to be destructive to coconut trees.
(N.) clay pot, used to cook viands. [also used as a nickname].
(N.) framework. (V.) babalangkas, mamalangkas ‘construct’; balangkasan, belangkas, pa:balangkas, magpabalangkas, paki-balangkas, abalangkas, apabalangkas. (D.) mabalangkas.
(N.) a grass or reed which grows near river banks and is used to weave mats and hats.
(N.) sand. Also the name of a barrio of Bacolor. (V.) ma:malasmala’s ‘feels sandy’.
(N.) eggplant. [metaphor] penis. (V.) mamalase’nas [with the metaphorical sense]
(N.) ‘blow-out’–a party where one who has come on some good fortune pays all the expenses. (V.) mamala’tuq.
(N.) shattered pieces. kabalbal; pibalbalan ‘the pieces left intact when something has shattered’. (V.) mangabalbal, makabalbal, makibalbal, pakibalbal, pabalbal, abalbal, apabalbal. (D.) mabalbal.

(N.) beard. pekabalbas ‘a fake beard’. (D.) mabalbas ‘bearded’; balbasan ‘bearded’. (V.) mamalbas ‘shave self’; magpabalbas ‘get shaved’; mangabalbasan ‘let beard grow’; makapamalbas; pa-pagbalbasan ‘tell someone to get a shave’.
(D.) crippled, lame. (V.) mangabaldadu, makapagbaldadu, makibaldadu, pa:baldadu, apabaldadu.

(V.) fall down. bildug; a:baldug ‘fell accidentally’; ke:baldug ‘caused to fall’; pa:baldug ‘cause to fall; translate’; magpabaldug ‘let self drop behind others’. (N.) kabaldugan ‘meaning’; baldugan-panyuq ‘drop-the-handerchief’.
(N.) a lending system, called ‘five-six’; 20% interest, payment daily. (V.) mamaldug.
(N.) house. makibale’ ‘house owner, housewife’; kasi’ping-bale’ ‘neighbor’; balebalayan ‘play-house’.
(N.) town. kabalen ‘townmate’; kabalenan ‘the town proper’; me:malen ‘the townspeople’; mibalenbalen ‘related to each other as from the same town’. (D.) pambalen ‘civic’.
(N.) a woven shopping bag or basket.
(V.) mag-ba’lik ‘return’; i-balik ‘return something’; balikan ‘return to somewhere’; pabalikan ‘return something’. (N.) kabalik ‘opposite, opponent’. kabalikan ‘reverse’. (D.) maybalik ‘be elected’.
(D.) crooked, twisted, incorrect. balidbali’d ‘ungrammatical speech’. (N.) kabalidbalid ‘errors in grammar’.

(D./St.) backwards. mabaligtad, makabaligtad. (N.) baligta’rin ‘reversible cloth, political turncoat, one who speaks ambiguously’. (V.) magbaligtad ‘tumble backwards’. pabaligtad, pakibaligtad, ke:baligtad, a:baligtad, mibaligtad. i-baligtad ‘reverse something, turn something inside-out’.

(N.) a person who ‘backbites’, i.e., says nice things in your presence but derogates you in your absence. A somewhat sour, segmented fruit [some speakers say this is not Kapampangan but Tagalog–see taranatiq].
(N.) edge of ear. (V.) balimbinga’n ‘to flick edge of another’s ear, as parents mildly punish children’.

(D.) mabaling ‘smelling of urine’. bali’sa (D.) restless, constantly moving. bali’taq (N.) news, clue. (V.) magbalitaq ‘spread news’; mamalitaq; ibalitaq ‘tell someone something’; makibalitaq ‘share news’; balita’nan ‘inform someone’; mibali’taq, mipamali’taq ‘be informed’.
(N.) level, grade, rung of a ladder. (V.) mamalitang ‘repair or install ladder rungs’.
(N.) a species of tree, said to be a favored place of spirits. A barrio of San Fernando.
(N.) a medicinal concoction, made from boiling gizzard of duck or chicken in salt and water. Said to be a remedy for appendicitis.
(N.) embalmer. (V.) balsamwan ‘to embalm someone’; panambalsamwan. (D.) mabalsamu ‘embalmed’.
(N.) knowledge. mikibaluq, makibaluq ‘people who know’. (V.) balwan, belwan ‘know something’; pabaluq ‘inform; ipabaluq; a:baluq ‘informed’; tabaluq ‘don’t know’.
(V.) mamaltang ‘take a shortcut’. makapamaltang ‘able to be shortened’. (N.) pa:mamaltang ‘shortcut, the taking of a shortcut’; baltanga’n ‘a shortcut’.
(N.) cashew (‘Queen of the fruits, because it sits on a throne’).
(D.) bent, curled up. makabaluktut ‘in a bent position’; mibaluktut ‘got bent’. (V.) magbaluktut, pa:baluktut, pamaluktut, a:baluktut, makibaluktut, pakibaluktut.
(N.) Negrito [generally used as a term of opprobrium].
(N.) ear(s); bottom of the macopa fruit. (V.) balugbuga’n ‘hit in the ear’.
(N.) gizzard, intestines. -balungus (N.) kuskus-balungus ado, fuss. (D.) kabalungusan (!).
(V.) babalusbus winnow (rice). mamalusbus, pa:balusbus, pakibalusbus, a:balusbus. 2. to mull over the meaning of something.

(V.) ba’lut, ibalut ‘wrap something’. magpabalut ‘have someone wrap’; makibalut, pakibalut, a:balut, mibalut. (D.) mabalut, makabalut. (N.) balutan ‘thing wrapped’; pipag-balutan ‘thing used to wrap’.
(N.) aged but unhatched duck egg eaten as a delicacy, snack.
(D.) holy, sacred. Ding Banal a Kasulatan ‘The Holy Scriptures’.
(D.) slow (speech) (speed, e.g. in driving). (V.) banayaran, benayaran ‘reduce speech’; magbanayad ‘decelerate’.
(N.) musical band. (D.) mikiba’nda ‘be in possession of a band’.
(Prep.) proceeding, towards. (V.) magbanda ‘go towards’; ibanda ‘move something’; a:banda ‘something can be moved’l. (D.) makabanda ‘situated towards’.
(N.) a woven basket, large, with handles.
(N.) wealth, possessions. mikibandi ‘owner’; ingat-bandi ‘treasurer’; pibandian ‘possessions’. (V.) pabandi ‘possess, obtain’; pakibandi. (D.) mabandi ‘owning, rich’; peka-mabandi ‘richest’.
(N.) musical combo, usually guitar and violin, sometimes accordion.
(N.) silt, erosion. Name of a sitio in Bacolor. (D.) mibabanlikan ‘silted over’.
(N.) alias, nickname. (D.) famous. (V.) bansagan, binsagan ‘nickname someone’.
(V.) guard, watch over. magbante, banten, binte, pa:bante, makibante, pakibante, a:bante. (N.) bante-plasdan ‘fishpond caretaker’; bantayan ‘a watching place, waiting shed’.
(N.) wires used to brace nipa houses in typhoons. (V.) pa:banting ‘put up bracing wires’. (D.) mabanting ‘braced’.
(N.) a furled leaf. suman-ba’nus ‘a rice delicacy of the suman type, wrapped in banus’.
(N.) year; sky; heaven. pabanwa ‘a whole year, first year’. (D.) banwaqan ‘annually’; banwa-banwa ‘annually’.
(N.) jar made of clay, often for holding drinking water.
(V.) divide, split. babangal, binangal; bangalan; magpa-bangal; pabangal; pa:mangal; makibangal; pakibangal. (N.) kabangal ‘a piece’; pa:mamangal ‘division’. (D.) mabangal.
(N.) a woven coverless basket, like a salikap but with rounded corners.
(N.) bank, where one stores money. (V.) magpabangko ‘put money in a bank’; makapagpabangko. (St.) makibangko.
(N.) a tool–long pole with curved metal blade–used for cutting bamboo. (V.) bangkuran ‘cut with bangkud’; pa:bangkud, pakibangkud, a:bangkud. (D.) me:bangkud.
(N.) rice crust, the rice at the bottom of the pot. (V.) mamangiq.
(St./D.) mabangu’ngut ‘have a nightmare, be affected by a seizure during sleep. Sometimes fatal and said to be caused by over-eating of rice. Old folks disapprove discussing this’.
(N.) milk-fish. bangusa’n ‘a disease of skin on face near mouth, sign of a curse’. mestiso-bangus [used to tease].
(N.) stud (male hog, goose, cow, horse, carabao, human).
(N.) balustrade, or the part of a wall with balustrade and shutters.
(N.) gang, one’s group of intimates. kabarka’da ‘one related to speaker as member of same gang’. (V.) papagbarkadan ‘make to join a gang’; a:kabarkada.
(N.) crowbar. (V.) magbareta ‘use a crowbar’; baretan, beretan ‘use a crowbar on…’; pa:bareta, pakibareta, a:bareta, a:pa:bareta. (D.) mabareta ‘worked on by a crowbar’.
(N.) gun. (V.) mamari’l ‘shoot’; barila’n ‘shoot something’; berilan, be:ril. (D.) mabaril.
(N.) marble-sized clay balls used as sling-shot ammunition.
(V.) i-barongga ‘throw something’; baronggan ‘throw at something’. (N.) barunggan-lata ‘kick-the-can’.
(N.) dress, shirt, clothing. (V.) magba’ruq ‘put on a dress’; mamaruq ‘wearing a dress’; pa:maruwan ‘dress someone’; makapabaruq.
(V.) barugan ‘beat someone, whip’. berugan, pemarug. (D.) mabarug.
(N.) barrio. kabaryu, barrio ‘mate’; mamaryu, memaryu ‘barrio folk’. (V.) makipamaryu ‘be from the same barrio’.
(D.) mabasa’q ‘wet’. mamasa:masaq ‘moist’. (V.) magbasa’q ‘get wet’; basa’n ‘wet something, soak something, irrigate something’. (N.) basa’n ‘rag, mop’.
(D.) rude, crude, improper. (N.) kabastusan; bastus ‘the name of one of the suits of cards in monte’. (V.) bastusan ‘to act crude to someone’; bistusan.
(N.) a kind of folk song. (V.) mamasulto, magpabasulto, pabasulto.
(N.) garbage. basure’ru ‘garbageman’; basuraqan ‘garbage dump’. (D.) mabasura ‘full of garbage’.
(V.) magbata’ ‘suffer, tolerate, endure’. makipibata; pibatan ‘tolerate something’; ipa:bata ‘make one be patient about something’.
(D.) resistant, full of endurance. A piece of wood from guava tree, shaped like a seven and used in circumcisions.
(N.) neck. (V.) batala’n ‘hit in the neck’; mipamatal.
(N.) small mixing bowl for sauce; see maninilyu.
(D.) mabati’ng ‘lost’. (V.) mangabating, makabating, a:bating, pa:mating, ke:mating.
(N.) stone, rock. saki’t king batu’ ‘kidney-stones’; batung mete ‘sandstone’; batung mabye.
(N.) a metal pan used for laundry!
(N.) smell. (V.) babau ‘smell’; bauan ‘smell something’; a:babau; pa:mau; pa:mauan; makibau; pakibau; pa:bau. (D.) mabau.
(N.) garlic; a kind of firecracker. bawang-bawang ‘a kind of vine the leaf of which smells like garlic’.
(N.) deduction, what is missing, what has been subtracted. (V.) bawasan, ibawas, bewas.
(N.) ember. (V.) magpabaya ‘make glow’; pabaya ‘make something glow with heat’.
(N.) guava(s), a kind of fruit. bayabasan ‘place where there are guavas’. (V.) mamayabas ‘gathering guavas’.
(N.) testicles. (V.) bayagan ‘hit in testicles’. pakibayag, a:pabayag, mipamayag. (D.) mebayag ‘hurt in the testicles’.
(V.) mag-bayansel [Eng. buy-and-sell] ‘work as a middleman, work on black-market’; mipagbayansel, pakipayansel.
(N.) weight. (V.) babayat ‘get heavy’. a:bayat, papabayatan ‘make heavier’, pasimbayatnan. (D.) mabayat ‘heavy’.
(N.) 1. affinal siblings. 2. organization ‘brothers’ or ‘sisters’. (V.) pa:bayo’ ‘pretend to be a bayo’; a:bayo ‘became a bayo’; mibayo ‘be related as bayo’.
(D.) new, newly. (Subcomb.) before. (V.) manimayu ‘changing’; mibabayu ‘being changed’.
(V.) magbayu ‘pound, grind (rice)’. magpabayu, maka:bayu, makapagpabayu, pa:bayu, mangabayu, pakibayu, a:bayu, ibayu, ipamayu. (D.) mabayu.
(V.) magbayutuk ‘bend, sag’; ibayutuk, beyutuk ‘bend something’; makabayutuk, makapagbayutuk; mibayutuk, mipabayutuk.
(N.) edge, especially of a body of water. (D.) makabebe ‘situated at the edge’. (V.) bebebe ‘go along the edge’.
(N.) 1. creche, Christmas nativity scene. 2. a female name.
(N.) blessing, benediction. (V.) magbendisyun, pabendisyon, be-bendisyunan, mangabendisyunan; a:bendisyunan, a:pabendisyun, paki-bendisyun.
(N.) furrows, a long line of rice paddies (see ba’nus ?).

(N.) night, evening. na:be’ngi ‘last night’. (D.) bengibe’ngi ‘nightly’; ma:be’n-gi ‘be overtaken by night’. (V.) magpabe’ngi ‘stay overnight, do something overnight’; ke:be’ngian ‘be overtaken by night because of something’.
(N.) a gambling game with three dice. (V.) magbetubetoq ‘play betobeto’.
(N.) a delicacy, stuffed and roasted frog. [metaphor] ‘a pregnant woman’.
(N.) (rice)cake delicacy of many different varieties, e.g. bibingkang du’man, bibingkang mai’s.
(N.) coconut shell. bikan lalaki ‘(top half of c.s.)’; bikan babai ‘(lower half of c.s.)’. [metaphor] ‘skull’.
(N.) a kind of dessert made from glutinous rice.
(N.) high clouds; halo around the moon.
(Q.) suddenly, straightaway. bigla:bigla’q. (V.) pa:biglaq; pa:miglaq ‘do something’; pamiglan ‘abruptly’.
(N.) religious restrictions such as fasting on specified days.
(V.) dry in sun (clothes, rice, meat, fish, wood). i-bilad, pa:bilad, a:bilad. (D.) me:bilad. (N.) bilaran ‘place for drying’.
(N.) count, sum. bila’ngan; kabilangan ‘total’; pa:-mamilang. (V.) mamilang, magabilang, bilangan, pa:bilang, pakibilang. (D.) mabilang.
(N.) wife of a brother-in-law or husband of a sister-in-law. (St.) mibilasbilas.
(V.) put down, drop. ibili ‘put something down’; pa:bili, pakibili.
(D.) mabili’s ‘swift, fast’. (V.) bilisan ‘speed something up’; ibilis, pa:malisan, pakibilisan, pa:-bilis, a:abil.
(D.) mabi’lug ‘round’. bilugbi’lug ‘very round’. (V.) bilu’gan ‘make round’; magbilug ‘form a circle’; mangabilug, magpabilug, pa:bilug, pa:milug. (N.) kabilugan ‘entirety; full moon’.
(N.) wine (a medicinal drink)–taken by women as medication for menstrual difficulties or after giving birth.
(N.) twenty-five centavo coin. binting walu ‘thirty-centavo coin’. [given as examples of obsolete Kapampangan].
(N.) a net for catching crabs. (V.) magbintu’l ‘use a bintul’. mamintul, makapamintul.
(N.) christening, baptism. binyagan ‘baptismal ceremony’. (V.) maminyag ‘perform bap. ceremony’; binyagan ‘baptise someone’; pa:binyag ‘have someone baptised’. (D.) mabinyag.
(N.) a substance used for patching leaks in bancas, also used as medicine for boils.
(N.) joke. kabiruwa’n ‘one teased’. (V.) biruwan ‘tease someone’. pa:biruq, makibiruq, pakibiruq, pa:-miruq. (D.) mabiruq.
(N.) visitor; see da’lo. pa:magbisita ‘visitation’. (V.) mamisita ‘visit’; magbisita ‘visit’; makibisita, pa:bisita, a:bisita, pakibisita.
(N.) vice, hobby, custom, preoccupation. (V.) magbisyu, mangabisyu, makibisyu. (D.) mabisyu.
(V.) carry with arm(s) hanging fully extended. mamitbit, bibitbitan, a:bitbit, kabitbit.
(N.) a kind of basket; holder, railing.
(V.) swirl, sort rice from chaff by swirling in a basket. bibitse, magbitse, mamitse, bibitcan, pa:mitse.
(N.) intestines. (D.) me:bituka ‘be hurt in the intestines’.
(N.) life. (V.) live. (D.) mabiye ‘alive’. See bye, bie.
(N.) a dish of food consisting of fish or meat shaped into ball.
(D.) stupid. bolangbolang; kabolangan ‘very, very stupid’; a:bolang; mekabolang.
(V.) magbo’rles ‘go naked, act indecently’. pa:borles, a:borles, makiborles. (D.) makaborles ‘indecent, contributing to indecency’; maborles.
(N.) voice. kabo’sis ‘one who has the same-sounding voice as another’. (V.) pa:bosis ‘listen to another’s voice (to establish identity)’. pakibosis, a:bosis, a:bosisan.
(N.) bottle. magboboti ‘bottle-buyer’. (V.) (magboti) ??. (D.) maboti ‘have plenty of bottles’.

(V.) magbo’tu ‘vote’. magpabotu ‘get someone to vote’; i-botu ‘vote for someone’; makabotu, makapagpabotu ‘can be elected’; pakibotu, a:botu, pa:botu, pa:motu. (N.) pipagbotwan ‘polling place, subject voted on’.
(N.) brush. (V.) magbro’ca ‘use a brush’; mamu-roca [sexual meaning].
(N.) witch, ugly personality. (V.) magbru’ha ‘be a witch, act nasty’.
(N.) bubunga’n ‘roof’. (V.) magbubung ‘fix a roof’; mag-pabubung ‘get the roof fixed’; maka-pagpamubung ‘can fix roofs’; apabubung ‘already had roofed’. (D.) mebubung ‘roofed’.
(V.) boil. bubuka, binukal; mikal, bumukal ‘sprout’; bukala’n ‘give one a lump’; pa:bukalan; pakibukalan; pakabukalan ‘boil something thoroughly’. (D.) mabukal.
(N.) tomorrow. kabukasan ‘the next day’. (V.) magpabukas ‘put off till tomorrow’. (D.) kabukas ‘overnight’; kinabukas ‘spent the night’.
(N.) a wood-boring insect. (D.) mabukbuk ‘bukbuk-infested’. mikabukbuk, mengabukbukan, bukbukan.
(V.) open. bi:klat. (N.) kabuklat ‘break (of dawn)’. buklatan ‘open something’; ibuklat, pa:muklat, pa:buklat, a:buklat, apa-buklat, makabuklat.
(N.) round bone at side of ankle.
(N.) bud of a fruit (coconut, mango) or flower (sampagita, gumamela). (V.) ma:mukuq.
(D.) makabu’kud ‘separated’. (V.) magbu’kud ‘live apart’; paki-bu’kud, aibukud, mibukud.
(N.) lump, swelling boil (on skin). (D./St.) ma:bukul ‘has many lumps’. ma:bukulan, mi:bukulan, a:bukulan, ke:bukul.
(V.) strike with thrown object. mamugaq, a:bugaq, pakibugaq.
(N.) bruise, lump. (V.) bugbuga’n ‘bruise someone’. mamugbug, makibugbugan, mibugbugan, makapamugbug. (D.) mabugbug ‘bruised’.
(D.) mabugtuq, mebugtuq ‘gasping (the manner of breathing of one near death)’.
(N.) riddle. bugtungang ‘riddle contest’; peka-bugtung; bugtung ayanak ‘only child’. (V.) bugtungan ‘make riddles’; mi-bugtungan ‘ask each other riddles’.
(N.) bubble. (V.) bubulaq, magbulaq, makibulaq, pabulaq, pakabulaq, pa:mulan. (D.) mabulaq ‘bubbly’.
(N.) cotton. (kapok? see bula’). (D.) mabulak, kabulak; pekamubula, makibulak.
(V.) bubu’lad ‘talk, answer back’. makabulad, pa:bularan, mi:bularan. (D.) mabulad, bularan ‘talkative’.
(V.) bulasan ‘be spoken to angrily’. bilasan, pa:bulas. (N.) kabubulas.
(N.) worm(s). (D.) mabulati ‘worm-infested’; maka-bulati ‘likely to give worms (e.g. food)’.

(N.) down, small feathers or hair. bulbul kilikili ‘hair in armpits’. (D.) mabulbul ‘with abundant down’; bulbulin ‘hairy’; me:mulmul ‘defeath-ered’. (V.) mamulmul ‘defeather’; makapa-mulmul ‘can defeather’; bulbulan, bilbulan, pa:mulbulan.
(N.) buttocks; rear of a bus or truck. (V.) bulditan ‘strike in buttocks’; bilditan ‘struck in buttocks’.
(N.) 1. rice dust. 2. a wild bamboo used to make sawali walling material. 3. fine hairs on stalk of sugar-cane, very itchy. (D.) mikibu’luq ‘fuzzy’.
(D.) rotten, fetid. mabuluk. (V.) pa:buluk ‘allow to become fetid’.
(N.) leaf; page of a book. (D.) mabulu’ng ‘leafy’.
(V.) whisper. bubulung, bulungan ‘whisper something’; bilungan, bilung; ma:mulung, pa:bulung; a:bulung; mibubulungan.
(N.) a kind of banana, green and about 10 inches long (fruit).
(V.) shout. bubulyo, mamulyo, pa:mulyo, bulyo’n ‘shout at someone’, bilyon, mipabulyo, pakibulyo.
(V.) pump, spray. mamumba; makapamumba; bumban ‘spray something’; pa:bumba; pakibumba; i-bumba ‘spray something for one’; pa-mumban. [metaphor] ‘have sexual intercourse’.
(N.) a kind of soil, mixed clay and sand. cf. bu(h)angin
(N.) puto-bumbong ‘a kind of bamboo; rice cake, steamed through bamboo tubes’.
(N.) mountain. bundukbundu’kan ‘hilly land’; bulubundu’kan ‘the Mountain Prov(s)’. (D.) mabunduk ‘mountainous’.
(N.) fruit. bungang-aldo ‘heat-rash’. (V.) mamunga ‘bear fruit’; pa:bungan ‘share-crop’. mabunga ‘bearing fruit abundantly’.
(D.) lacking front teeth. mabungal. (V.) pabungal, pa:mungal, pakibungal, ke:bungalan.
(D./St.) split, shattered, having a harelip or lacking front teeth. (V.) a:bungiq, me:bungiq.
(N.) baby, youngest in a family. pekabunsu’ ‘the youngest’.
(N.) a hat made of woven and starched reeds or grasses.
(N.) head. [metaphor] ‘chief, front of truck’. (V.) mamuntuk ‘carry on head’. See puntuk.
(N.) pile, stack. bu’ntun-a’re ‘haystack’. (V.) buntunan, bintunan; ibuntun; pa:muntun; pakibuntun; mibuntun.
(N.) coconut husk used for polishing floors. (V.) mamunut, bunutan ‘husk-polish something’, pakibunut, a:bunut, mabunut.
(N.) mud. bu’rak-biti’s ‘farmer [derogatory]’; bura’kan ‘a muddy place’; pipagburakan ‘wallowing hole’. (D.) maburak ‘muddy’. (V.) buburakan ‘put in mud (e.g. balut)’; magburak ‘play with mud’.
(N.) kite. pipagburarulan ‘a place to fly kite’. (V.) mamurarul, makapamurarul.
(V.) pull back foreskin of penis. buburat, birat; pa:murat.
(V.) like, want, find pleasure in. pa:buriq ‘make self liked’. (D.) maburiq. (N.) buriq ‘thing liked’.

(N.) rods used in working bamboo, in fishing and elsewhere, as lances in a contest in which bicycle-riders attempt to spear small rings hung on ribbons across the path. Also bingo counters and bowling pins.
(N.) preserved eggs, ‘red eggs’. (V.) mamuro, paburu, makapamuro ‘to salt to preserve’.
(V.) insert between two things. busalan, pabusalan, pabusal, ibusal. (N.) busal ning mais ‘corncob’.

(N.) hole. busbus ipan ‘cavity’; busbus arung ‘nostril’; busbus butunis ‘button hole’. (V.) busbusan ‘bore, poke hole(s) in’; bisbusan [fig.] ‘penetrate a virgin’; mamusbus, pa:musbus, a:busbus, ibusbus. (D.) mabusbus, makabusbus.
(N.) horn (for blowing, auto horn). (V.) bubusina ‘blow horn’; mamusina; makibusina; pamusinan; ibusina.
(D./St.) opened, unlocked. busniq, bisniq, makabusniq. (V.) ibusniq ‘open something’; pe:-musniq, a:busniq, pa:busniq, a:pabusniq; mamusniq, pakibusniq, mibusniq, makipamusnyan, mangabusniq.
(N.) calf of leg. (V.) butitan ‘hit in calf’; bititan.
(N.) seed, stone, bone. pangabutul ‘size of seed’; utak ning butul ‘bone marrow’. (D.) mikibutul ‘having seed(s)’.
(N.) button(s). (V.) butunisan ‘button something up’; mamutunis ‘one who puts on button’; makapamutunis ‘can sew on button’.
(V.) lift, carry. ibuwat, binwat, a:buat, mangabuat, magpabuat, makapamwat, makibwat, mibwat, pa:muat, mamuat. (D.) mebuwat.
(N.) hair. bwakbwakan/bwakbwakin ‘hair on arms or forehead’. (D.) mabuak ‘have hair on (as after a haircut)’.
(N.) pest, disturbance, bore, nuisance. (V.) bwisitan ‘bother someone’; binuwisit; magbwisit/magbusit; mamusit; mapamusit.
(N.) a fishing net, pocket-shape, used by one man in a current. biyaku’san/bayakusan ‘banca used in such fishing’. (V.) mamayakus.
(N.) journey, trip. (V.) magbyahe ‘take a trip, go around on display (for sale)’.

(N.) life. pamibyebye ‘ways of life’; byeran-delanan ‘life-testimonial’; kabyayan ‘occupation, making a living’; pangabyayan, pengabyayan ‘source of life’; byayan ‘hatchery’. (D.) mabye ‘alive, living’. (V.) mye ‘live, be alive’.
(N.) scar. (D.) mabyuk ‘scarred’; mikabyuk. (V.) byukan ‘give a scar to someone’; pa:myukan.
(N.) roaring sound. (V.) biyung, binyung; mamyung, memyung.

1. personal pronoun, ‘you’ (Sg.); ing-case, non-emphasized. ka- 2. prefix with descriptive bases produces emphatic descriptives. 3. prefix with verb and noun bases produces nouns; ka- + noun produces a noun meaning one of a type, partner in… 4. prefix with cardinal numbers produces ordinal numbers.
(N.) length. (V.) kakabaq, kakaban ‘lengthen something’; magpakabaq ‘stretch self’; pakikabaq; ikabaq; a:kabaq; pakabaq; pakaban; mipakabaq. (D.) makabaq; makabakabaq.
(N.) meaning, significance; see baldug. (V.) mangabaldugan ‘have a meaning’.
(N.) the barrio of Bacolor which in the town proper.
(N.) counterpart, one of a pair. kaba’ngal a salu’q ‘spouse’.
(N.) cabaret, nightclub + dance hall. (V.) mangabaret ‘go to a cabaret’; makapangabaret.
(N.) coffin. (D.) makakabaung ‘in a coffin’. (V.) ikabaung ‘put someone in a coffin’; pakabaung.
(N.) horse. pakabayu ‘sawhorse, ironing-board’. (V.) kabaywan ‘ride horseback on a person’; magabayu, pangabayu; pa:kabayu ‘give horseback ride’.
(N.) head (in a figurative sense), leader. kabise’ra ‘capitol’. (D.) makakabesa ‘sit at the head of the table’.
(V.) put, fix, attach. mangabit, pa:kabit, pakikabit, ikabit, pa:ngabit, ka:bitan, makapangabit. (N.) kabi’t ‘common-law wife’.
(N.) electric wires, cable, other wire. kabligra’ma ‘cablegram’.
(N.) the next day; see bukas. (V.) kebukasan ‘kept until the next day, held (e.g.) busy overnight’.
(Q.) unexpectedly, unannounced. kabudkabud; [syntactically comparable to agad].
(V.) kakabyus ‘by-pass, go askew’. kinabyus, a:kabyusan, mikabyus, pa:ngabyus.
(V.) stutter. mangakakak ‘stutter repeatedly’; me:kakak. (D./St.) makakak ‘conducive to stuttering’.
(D.) deaf. maklak, makaklak. (V.) mangaklak, a:kaklak, apakaklak.
(N.) chain. (V.) ikadena ‘chain something’; a:kadena, kakadena, kinadena.
(V.) kakagliq ‘is conceiving’ i.e. ‘is in first two months of pregnancy’. kigliq, mangagliq, makikagliq, a:kaglian, keglian, pengiglian ‘crave something while conceiving’. (N.) pa:mangagliq.
(N.) a kind of insect (flea, tic?). (D.) makago ‘bitten by kago’.

(N.) [full-word filler, empty semantically]. ‘watch-a-ma-call-it, you-know-who/what-I-mean’. (D.) makai ‘like you-know-how’; makakai ‘in such-and-such a state’; potang kai ‘indefinite future’; ketang kai ‘indefinite past’. (V.) mangai, kakai, kayan, kinyan, makakai ‘able to do it’, makikai, pakikai, pa:kai, pangakai.
(N.) the hot season. (V.) makipagkalaldo ‘spend the summer’.
(N.) contents, table of contents; see laman.
(N.) tapping noise. (D.) makalampag ‘noisy, has lots of tapping’. (V.) mangalampag, makikalampag, pa:kalampag, pangalampag.
(N.) (promiscuity), state of being in heat; see landi.

(N.) stove, place where the cooking fire is kept. kala’ng-u’ling ‘charcoal stove’; pagkalangan ‘cooking place’; pekakalang ‘stones which hold pot over the fire’. (V.) mag-tungkung-kalang ‘sit or squat with two others, in the same positions as the pot stones’.
(V.) scatter. magkalat, magkalatkalat; pangalat, makikalat; pa:kalat, ikalat; mipakalat, mikakalat, a:kalat. (D.) makalat.
(N.) swelling, lump. (St./V.) swell, be swollen. mangalbag, makikalbag, pa:kalbagan. (D.) makalbag ‘swollen’; inundated. (also used of a hose used to check levels in carpentry–water and air bubble).
(V.) pinch, pressure. mangalbit, pakikalbit, pa:kalbit, pangalbit, kakalbitan, a:kalbit, makapangalbit, pangalbitan.
(N.) carbide (used for lighting fishing lanterns and also as explosive in bamboo cannons).
(N.) storage place and equipment in a part of sugar extracting.
(N.) two-wheel horse-drawn carriage. (V.) mangalesa ’ride a calesa. (D.) makalesa ‘many calesas in a place’.
(N.) a meat stew, usually with dog or goat as the main ingredient (quite spicy).
(V.) kalisan ‘cut (hair–as scraping a pig’s carcass, grass, cane)’. mangalis, pakikalis, makikalis, a:kalis, makapangalis, pa:ngalis. (D.) makalat.
(V.) chug, rumble (e.g. jeep motor, hungry stomach). kakalugkug, makikalugkug, mangalugkug. (D.) makalugkug.
(N.) ka:luguran ‘friend’; kalugura’n ‘sweetheart’. (V.) kalugura’n ‘love someone’; see lugu’d.
(N.) a poor person. (V.) pa:kaluluq, ke:kaluluq. (D./St.) paka:kaluluq, pa:ngakaluluq ‘very poor’, kakaluluwan.
(N.) corn, callus. (V.) magkalyu ‘get calluses’, maka-pangalyu. (D.) makalyu, makikalyu, mangakalyu.
(N.) relatives, family relationship. (V.) makikamaganak ‘posing as relatives’; see anak.
(N.) a deadly snake, black or maroon in color (cobra?).
(N.) a kind of cricket, eaten fried or cooked with tomatoes.
(N.) twin. (V.) kakambal, mikambal. (Q.) kambal kami malan ‘we are wearing matching clothes’.
(N.) a small moth which damages rice and sugar cane.
(N.) gears, gearshift; railraod switch. (V.) mangambyu, a:kambyu, mipakambyu.
(Substitute: personal pronoun) we (excluding person spoken to).
(N.) church bells. kampana’ryu ‘bell tower’. (V.) magkampanaq ‘ring church bells’.
(N.) 1. a kind of suman wrapper. 2. a long Moro knife. kampila’n.
(N.) an edible tuber, cassava. kamuting-du’tung, kamuting-ba’gin.
(N.) kakanan ‘food’. kanan, pa:mangan, pe:ngan ‘thing eaten’. (V.) mangan, mengan; pengan; a:pangan; pa:pakan ‘feed someone’; makipangan.
(N.) canal, ditch. (D.) mekanal ‘fell in a ditch’. (V.) pa:kanal ‘have a ditch dug’.
(N.) Candaba (the name of both a town and a large swamp in Pampanga).
(N.) a yellow and black spider found in trees.
(V.) mangandung ‘carry in lap’. kandunga’n ‘put someone in lap’. (N.) kandu’ngan ‘lap’.
(V.) kakandutan ‘pinch with a twisting motion’. kandutandutan, mikandutandutan.
(N.) corner. (V.) magkantukantu ‘stand around on the corner’; pakantukantu.
(Adjunct: discourse particle) reportative, i.e. it is said, they said, he said, it seemed.
(Substitute) now, like that. makanyan. (V.) pa:kanyan, a:kanyan.
(D.) appropriate, fitting, suited, at ease with. kapadkapad. (V.) maningapad.
(N.) thickness. (D.) makapal ‘thick, wide’; makapal a lupaq ‘thick-faced’. (V.) pakapalan ‘make something thick’; a:kapal.
(N.) Capiz, a province of Panay, believed to be the home of aswang.
(Q.) together. (N.) a type of banana, grows with the fruit bunched together. (V.) kapi’tan ‘be close to someone, especially to one in power’.
(N.) midnight; see kapitnaq. (V.) mengapitangang-bengi ‘stayed up until midnight’.
(N.) raincoat or jacket. (D.) makakapoti ‘wearing a kapoti’. (V.) magkapoti, papagkapotcan.
(N.) a spirit, said to be tall, black, smoking foot-long cigars, and appearing at night.
(N.) a finger measurement–the distance between thumb and middle finger.
(V.) ‘making babies’. kakarat, kinarat, makakarat, mangakarat, makikarat, ke:rat, pakikarat, magpakarat, pa:karat, pangarat, a:karat, ka:karatan. (D.) makarat. (N.) pa:mangarat.
(N.) carbide–a kind of lantern used for fishing.
(N.) baggage. (V.) carry. kargan, magpakarga, pakikarga, pa:karga, pa:ngarga, ikarga, a:karga, mipakarga. (D.) makarga.
(Substitute) location ‘there (far)’. kari’nyo (D.) makarinyo ‘loving’. mapangarinyo. (V.) mangarinyo, kerinyo, a:karinyo. (N.) karinyo’sa ‘1. beloved, a loving girl; 2. a type of banana’.
(N.) 1. a manual to be memorized; a literacy manual. 2. wheelbarrow.
(V.) kakarug ‘tremble’, kinarug, makikarug, pa:karug, a:pakarug. (D.) makarug.
(N.) wagon. (V.) mangaruwaye ‘ride in a …’, makikaruwaye, pe:ngaruwayi, maka:pangaruwayi.
(N.) marriage, wedding. talakasal, kasal-wes ‘civil ceremony’. (V.) kakasal, kinasal, ke:sal; ikasal; magpakasal; pa:kasal; pa:ngasal; a:kasal; mipakasal. (D.) makasal, me:kasal.
(N.) tantrum. (V.) kakasat ‘throw a tantrum’. kinasat, magkasat, a:kasat, ke:sat, pa:ngasat, pangakasat. (D.) makakasat ‘in a tantrum state’.
(V.) rub, scratch, grate. kakaskas, mangaskas, ikaskas, a:kaskas, mipakaskas, pa:ngaskas. (N.) kaskasan ‘thing to scratch’. (D.) makakaskas. See kiskis.
(N.) a type of banana [said to be called katoldan in Sexmoan].
(V.) flay (hack?). kinatat, katatan, ma:ngatat, pa:katat, pa:ngatat, a:katat. (D.) makatat.
(N.) low water-level. (V.) kakatih, magpakati, pakatyan, a:pakati. (D.) me:kati, kasingkati.
(D.) makes one numb; [also] name of a club.
(D.) filled (of a container). makatmuq, kitmuq. (V.) kumatmuq, kinatmuq, katmwan, pa:katmwan, pa:katmuq.
(N.) parent(s)-in-law. (V.) mangatuangan ‘going to the father-in-law’; pa:katuanga, a:katuangan.
(N.) box; one section of a fishpond. (V.) kaun ‘box something’. ke:un, a:kaun, pa:kaun, mikaun.
(V.) bark of a dog. kakaung. (N.) bark of a dog.
(V./St.) be separated, go separate way. maka:kawaniq [ability], mikawaniq, mika:kawaniq, mipakawaniq, makikawaniq, pakikawaniq, pa:kawaniq, ikawaniq, ke:waniq, pa:ngawaniq; makakawaniq ‘separated’.
(V.) swim (primarily refers to the hand stroke). kewe, kewen, ikawe, pa:kawen, pakikawe. (N.) pa:mangawe.
(N.) goodness; see mayap, qapqap, kumayap. (V.) kayap, kumayap ‘get well, recover’; mangayap; makakayap; pa:kayap; pa:kayapan; a:pakayap. (D.) makayap, mikayap, makikayap.
(V.) whittle. kayasan, ke:yasan, mangayas, makakayas, pa:kayas, pa:ngayas, a:kayas. (D.) makayas ‘whittled’.
(Subcomb.) marks relative. 1. clause (embedded sentence functioning as attribute). 2. Subst. = kami. 3. Subst., portmanteau: ku + ya.
1. substitute, locative ‘there’. 2. abbreviated form of keng.
(D./St.) makake’raq ‘resting, lying down’. (N.) pagkeran ‘bed, resting place’.
(V.) bite. ketan, kiketan, manget, mangaket, pakiket, a:ket, a:paket, iket, pe:nget, mipanget.

(V./St.) be acquainted. kakilala, mikilala, a:kilala, makikilala ‘recognize’; pakikilala, pakikilala ‘make known, introduce’; mipangilala, makakilala. (D.) makilala, mekilala, makakilala. (N.) pa:mangilala.
(N.) eyebrow; axillary hair; see kilikili. (V.) mangile ‘put on eyebrow/lash, makeup’. pa:kile, a:pakile.
(V.) kilikan ‘carry (a baby) on one’s hip’. mangilik, maka:kilik, pakikilik, a:kilik, pangikikan. (N.) pa:mangilik. (D.) makilik, mekilik, makakilik.
(N.) gesture, movement, campaign. (V.) kikilus, kinilus, kumilus.
(N.) [rare] puppet show, movie. (V.) kikimut ‘move around’. mangimut, pa:kimutan.
(V./St.) the whole night (past), did something all night; see bu’kas.
(V.) nip, nibble, be stung. kininis, kinisan, manginis. (D.) mekinis ‘was bitten, nipped, stung.
(V.) a motion of lower trunk. (N.) palkinyu’ran ‘buttocks, hips’.
(V.) tremble, vibrate. kikingking, kiningking, magingking, mipakingking, a:pakingking.
(N.) ceiling. pekakisami ‘ceiling material’. (V.) pa:kisami ‘have ceiling installed’, a:pakisami, makikisami. (D.) mikakisami ‘having a ceiling’.
(N.) a fine mesh fish net. (V.) ma:ngitig ‘fish with a kitig’. mengitig.
(V.) cry. kikyak, kumiyak, pa:kyakan ‘make someone cry’, ma:ngyak, kinyak, a:pakyak, mipakyak.
(N.) list to be memorized, sample ballot, cheat-sheet.
(N.) commander (Huk usage). (V.) magkomander ‘become, be a commander’; papagkomander.
(N.) comet (believed to be sign of times to come: good if the tail is above; bad if below).
(N.) Conde Irlos–the name of a famous corrido.

(N.) antidote, immunization, countermeasure. pa:mangontra, pa:ngontra. (V.) pakikontra ‘turn two screws in opposition’; makikontra ‘oppose another’; pa:kontra; pa:kontran; a:kakontra; mikontra. (D./St.) makakontra ‘in opposition’.
(N.) rice mill; see kiskisan. ma:ngonu ‘miller’. (V.) mangonu ‘mill (rice)’. makikonu, pa:konu, pa:ngonu, makapagkonu ‘have rice milled’. (D.) makonu.
(N.) one of the suits in the card game, monte.
(V.) copy. kopiyan ‘copy something’, ikopya, pakikopya, pa:kopya, pa:kopyan, a:kopya, pangopya. (N.) pamangopya ‘copying process’; pekakopya ‘a duplicate’.
(N.) car, automobile. (V.) magkotci ‘ride in a car’; mangotci; papangotcan. (D./St.) makakotci.
(N.) a verse-form contest, named after the first major Kapampangan poet and dramatist, Juan Crisostomo Soto. (V.) magkrisotan ‘engage in krisotan’. makikrisotan, papagkrisotan.
(N.) shack, small house in fields; see balebalayan.
(N.) silverware, eating utensils. (V.) mangubyertus ‘use utensils to eat’.
(N.) toe and finger nails. pekakuku ’artificial fingernail. (V.) manguku ‘cut one’s fingernails’; pa:kuku, pakikuku, pa:ngukuan, a:kuku, mipanguku. (D.) makuku.
(N./V.) cough. ma:ngukuq, makikukuq, mipakukuq, mangapanguku, magpakukuq.
(N.) a small hand-tool used for scraping the soft meat from young coconuts. (V.) kudkura’n ‘scrape (a coconut), scratch (hair, i.e. head)’.
(N.) square. pekakudradu ‘square shape’. (D.) makudradu. (V.) pa:kudradu, pangudradu, pangudradwan.
(N.) a scissors-like tool used for opening luyus. (V.) magkulakatiq.
(V.) cry out, shout, yell, scream. pangulait.

(N.) sorcery. magkukulam ‘sorcerer’, pangapangkukulam ‘the likeness of a sorcerer’. (V.) kulaman ‘bewitch someone’, ki:laman ‘was bewitched’, magpakulam, mangakulam, pakikulam, a:kulam, a:pangulam, makikulam, mipangulam. (D.) makulam, mekulam.

(Q.) lacking. (V.) magkulang ‘do wrong’, makikulang, pa:kulang, a:pakulang, ke:kulang; magkulangan, mangakulangan, pakikulangan, kakulangan, pa:ngulangan, ke:kulangan, kinulangan, a:kulangan. (D.) makulang, mekulang.
(N.) nasal mucus, snot. (D.) makulangut ‘have a head cold’.
(V.) go down, get off (a vehicle, a platform). manguldas, makakuldas, mipakuldas, mikuldas, pa:kuldas, pakuldasan, pa:nguldas, pakikuldas, a:kuldas. (N.) kulda’san ‘place to get off’.
(N.) a disease, sometimes has external symptoms, sometimes does not.
(V.) mangulekta/manguleksyun ‘collect, take up a collection’. makikolekta, pakikolekta, pangulekta/panguleksyun, a:kulekta/ a:kuleksyun. (N.) ma:ngulekta/kolekto’r.
(V.) ma:ngulti ‘soaking corns/calluses in a lime solution’. pangulti, pa:kulti.
(D.) the color of –. kululu’bi ‘violet (color of the ube tuber)’, kulule’bun ‘egg-colored’.
(St./V.) jailed, trapped. mangakulung, maka:kulung, pa:kulung, pakikulung, a:kulung, pa:ngulung, ikulung, pa:ngulungan, ke:kulung. (D.) makulung, makakulung. (N.) kulungan ‘jail’.
(V.) apply color. ma:ngulur, pa:kulur; kuluran, kiluran; pakikulur, a:kulur, pa:nguluran. (D.) makulur; see makule.
(St./D./V.) curl(ed). kulutan, kilutan, mangakulut, maka:kulut, makikulut, pakikulut, pa:kulut, a:pakulut, a:pangulutan, pa:ngulutan. (D.) makulut ‘curly’; makakulut.
(N.) the old name for what is now Angeles City.
(N.) convent, parish house, residence of a priest.
(V.) invite. mangumbira, kumbiran, kimbiran, makapangumbira, pakikumbira, pa:kumbira, a:kumbira, pa:ngumbira. (D.) makumbira. (N.) pa:mangumbira.
(N?) Confirmation–a Catholic ceremony. (V.) ma:ngumpil, mangakumpil, makikumpil, pakikumpil. (D.) makakumpil.
(N.) Concordias (name of a bridge in Cabalantian).
(N.) a melon (or squash?)–informants call it variously fruit or vegetable; eaten candied.
(N.) 1. almasiga resin (?). (Spanish copa) 2. semen; vaginal lubricant.

(N.) hat, cap (includes woven hats, caps such as policeman’s). kakupyaq ‘one who wears same hat’. (V.) magkupyaq ‘wear a hat’. pakikupya, makikupya, pa:kupya, pa:ngupyan, a:kupyaq. (D.) makakupyaq ‘wearing a hat’.
(N.) a large pot, used for cooking rice. Bakit, dadala ke wari ing kuran? Why, did you want the pot to bring me? [an idiomatic expression said to one who has kept you waiting].
(V.) blink eyes; see kirat. kukurap, magkurap, pa:kurapan, pa:ngurap, a:kurap, makakurap.
(N.) the hot season from February to May, the Lenten season. (Sp. cuaresma) (V.) magkurismaq ‘Lent is coming near’.
(N.) a Catholic retreat/revival movement, the organization, the meetings. (V.) magkursilyu ‘repent, change one’s ways, i.e. join the Cursillo’.
(N.) curtain. (V.) mangurtina, a:kortinan, pa:kurtina, pa:ngurtinan. (D.) makortina, makortinan.
(N.) crude oil, diesel fuel. (D.) makurudu ‘oily’; dekurudu ‘oil-burning’.

(N.) current, electric current. tulang kuriyente ‘a kind of dragonfly. (V.) magkuriyente ‘electrocute’, manguriyente, pa:kuriyente, panguriyente, a:kuriyente. (D.) makakuriyente, makuriyente ‘lively, full of energy’.
(N.) fuss, ado, bother, fancy frills. (D.) makuskusbalungus (kabalangusan).
(N.) kitchen (a separate building from the ‘house’–considered not a part of the house even when attached). (V.) ma:ngusina/magkusina ‘cook, work in the kitchen’.
(D.) makuswelu ‘be satisfied, be happy with something one has’.

(N.) question. kinutang ‘thing asked’; pa:mangutang ‘questioning, interrogative’. (V.) mangutang, ikutang, a:kutnan, kitnan, kitnanan, kitang, pa:ngutnan-mangakutang, mikutang, mipangutang, makikutang, pakikutang, pa:kutang, a:kutang.

(V./St.) bury. ma:ngutkut, kutkutan, pa:ngutkut, pa:kutkut, pakikutkut, ikutkut, a:kutkut, maka:kutkut, mipakutkut, kitkut, kakutkutkut ‘just buried’. (N.) kutkutan ‘cemetery; see kampu santu. (D.) makutkut, mekutkut, makakutkut.
(N.) skin-color, pigmentation. (V.) a:kuti’san ‘be recognized, be identified’.
(N.) spoon. (V.) mangutcaraq ‘use a spoon’; pa:ngutcaran ‘eat something with a spoon’. [said in Bacolor to mean ‘shovel’ in the Minalin dialect].
(N.) louse; see liyas. kutung-gaqinduq. (D.) makutu ‘lice-infested’. (V.) mangutu, mipangutu, makikutu.

(N.) something cut [Bergaño]; a section of San Fernando noted for its residents’ performing penitential acts on Good Friday. magkukutud ‘an evil person or witch said to be able to separate upper half of body from lower and fly; see aswang.
(N.) ‘mushroom’ in the Sta. Rita dialect, according to Bacolor informants.
(D.) makuyad ‘short, not long’. (V.) mangakuyad, pa:kuyad, pa:nguyad, pa:nguyaran, a:kuyad, ikuyad. (St.) makamakuyad.
(V.) get, take. kumaq, kuanan, ikwaq, kinwaq, mangwaq, manikwaq, ipakikwaq, pa:ngwaq, magpakwaq, a:kwaq, pa:ngwanan, pa:kwaq, ke:yakwaq, mipangwaq. (N.) pa:mangwaq ‘act of getting’.
(N.) money, a single coin. pikwaltan ‘source of wealth’. (D.) makwalta ‘rich, wealthy’; mikwalta.
(N.) spring, winding key. (V.) kwerda’san ‘wind something up’.
(V.) magkyuapus ‘imitate’; see a’pus. makakyapus, pa:kyapus, pa:kyapusan, makyapus, mikyapus.
(N.) a large, wide-mouth cooking pot, made of clay, black.
(N.) a male first name; a family name.
(N.) many, much. marakal, merakal, pekamarakal, kasing-dakal. (V.) a:parakal, ka:rakal, pa:ngarakal, pa:rakalan, miparakal.
(V.) catch, apprehend. magdakap, makarakap, manyakap, pakirakap, dakpan, darakpan, pa:nyakap, panyakpan, a:rakap. (D.) marakap, merakap.
(N.) phase, share, portion. dakedake ‘partition’, pa:mandake, pir:raka’yan. (V.) pa:rake, makidake, a:rake, mirake.
(V.) fetch home, escort home; see dalakit.
(V.) dagdagan ‘add, augment something’. digdagan, pandagdagan, magdagdag, makidagdag, pa:ragdag, a:dagdag, pakidagdag, miparagdag, mandagdag, mindagdag. (D.) madagdag, medagdag, makadagdag.
(N.) rat(s). dagi’s-bale’, dagi’s-pa’le. dagisdagi’san = tigsang dagis ‘a lump in flesh caused by a sharp blow’.

(V.) grow big(ger). daragul, dinagul, idagul, mandagul, mindagul, pa:ragul, a:dagul, pandagul, pindagul, pa:ragulan, miparagul. (D.) maragul, mangaragul, pekamaragul, kasingdagul. (N.) karagulan ‘bigness’; pa:magparagul ‘raising (children)’.
(N.) superior, more powerful. (V.) daig ‘overcome’, deig. daiga’n, deigan.
(V.) bring, carry. magdala, dalan, makidala, pakidala, pa:dala, maka:dala, pa:ndala, idala, a:dala, a:padala, mi:dala, mipadala. (D.) madala, medala, makadala.

(V.) see dakitan. da:lakit ‘come over, come across (e.g. go to a neighbor’s house)’. dinalakit, maka:dalakit, pakidalakit, pa:ndalakit, a:dalakit, mandalakit, mindalakit, midalakit, kadalakit. (N.) pekadalakitan ‘e.g. bamboos for crossing a stream or chasm’, pa:mandalakit ‘the act of crossing’.

(N.) maiden, virgin, young woman. (pl.) da:laga. See dumalaga, dalagita; kadalagan ‘a gathering of dalaga’. (V.) magdalaga ‘become a dalaga’. (D.) madalaga, medalaga; makidalaga ‘have a dalaga daughter’.
(N.) a young girl in pre-teen or early teen age; see dalaga. (V.) magdalagita ‘become a dalaga’. (D.) madalagita.

(N.) road, way, passage. (V.) dalanan ‘pass by for someone’. dinalan, pa:dalan, makidalan ‘pass between others’, pandalan, mandalan, mindalan, idalan, a:dalan, mipadalan, madalanan ‘made into a passage’.
(D.) madalas/maralas ‘often’. pekamadalas/pekamaralas, kasingdalas, makidalas. (V.) pa:ralas/pa:dalas, pandalas, idalas, a:dalas.
(V.) grind, pound, mill. daraldak, pa:daldak, iparaldak, idaldak, pakidaldak, a:daldak. (N.) pa:mandaldak, daldakan. (D.) madaldak, medaldak, makadaldak, kasing daldak.
(N.) a finger measurement–thumb and index finger.
(N.) crocodile. tulang dapu ‘a kind of dragonfly which is found at rivers’.
(N.) trash pile (e.g. leaves and other yard sweepings).
(Q./N.) self; [superlative constructions] ikandiliq ‘you alone’, malaguqdiliq ‘the prettiest’.
(N.) spirits, said to live in dapdap.
(V.) pounding rice [sometimes to the accompaniment of music].
(N.) port, depot, space behind a house; see kandungan ‘lap’.
(N.) bride-gifts. (V.) manduruq, pa:duruq, duruwan ‘bargain for something’.
(N.) punishment, curse of a parent on child for misdeed. kaparusan; pipagparusan.
(N.) God. spuq: Diyos puq [a greeting; what one says to announce his presence–like Americans knock on a person’s door].
(N.) a bundle of cut palay, about 25 legayan contained therein.
(N.) age; also a female nickname, from Natividad.
(N.) Elgin watch (a first-class watch); [metaphor] ‘serious case of veneral disease’.
(N.) air rifle [used in some dialects as in Maliualuq; elsewhere, as in Cabalantian: baril-pardigonis].
(N.) a female name. bua’k-nang-e’ster ‘an ornamental plant which has no roots’.
(N.) earth; soil, dirt. (V.) maggabun, makigabun, gabunan, ge:bunan.
(D.) magadtuq ‘(rice) cooked with too little water’. (V.) a:kagadtuq, pa:gadtuq, pagadtuwan, mipagadtuq.
(N.) motion, restless motion, disturbance. cf. kilus pa:manggalo. (D.) magalo ‘fidgety’. (V.) gagalo, maka:galo, pakigalo, pa:galo, a:galo, pa:ngalo, migalo.
(N.) galu’nggung ‘a long, ocean fish’. (V.) shiver, tremble (with cold).
(N.) hand [sometimes used to mean lower arm in general].
(V.) use. gagamit, ginamit, gumamit, mangamit, gamitan, igamit, pa:gamit, a:gamit, a:pagamit, pa:ngamit, pa:ngamitan, magpagamit, maka:gamit, mipagamit. (D.) magamit, megamit, makagamit.
(V./St.) migampaq ‘done because of some reason (?). pigampaq, pigagampan.

(V.) scratch; plow, rake. gamusan, ge:musan, ginamus, manggamus, makigamus, pakigamus, makapangamus, pa:gamus, a:gamus, pa:ngamus, mipangamus. (D.) magamus, megamus, makagamus ‘plowed’. (N.) pangamus ‘rake’.

(D.) maganakaq ‘virtuous, kind, thoughtful’. (V.) makaganakaq, pa:ganakaq ‘remind, give someone a hint’, a:ganakaq, mangaganakaq, pangaganakaq, miganakaq ‘be worried about’, ganakan ‘consider, remind, suggest’, gaganakan ‘worry about’, ge:nakan, pigaganakan. (N.) pa:miganakaq/pa:migaganakaq ‘dread, worry, anxiety’, ka:piga:ganaka’n ‘warning’.
(D.) perfect, finished, complete. makaganap ‘can be finished’. (V.) ganapan ‘finish something, accomplish something’, ge:nap, ge:napan.
(N.) dawn, early in the morning. (D.) manganingaldo ‘be an early bird’.

(V.) crawl. gagapang, ginapang, gumapang, gapangan ‘crawl to someplace [this, when used in discussion of sexual activity, refers to “stealing”, i.e. sneaking into a house at night and having intercourse with a “sleeping” girl]’. ge:pangan, ma:ngapang, makapangapang pakigapang, pa:gapang.
(V.) cut, as in harvesting rice. manggapas, magpagapas, pa:gapas, a:gapas, pakigapas, pangapas, gapasan, ge:pasan, igapas. (N.) panggapas ‘the tool used for…’.
(N.) binder, fetters, chain. (V.) gagapus ‘be bound, tied’. ginapus, gapusan, gagapusan, ge:pusan, manggapus, pa:gapus, a:gapus, igapus, makigapus, pakigapus, migapus. (D.) magapus, megapus.
(N.) sled, a farmer’s cart with wooden runners rather than wheels.
(N.) bangus at a stage of growth larger than biniq but smaller than adult.
(N.) kerosene. saynu-gas ‘cyanide (?)–a poison used on fish’; sulung-degas ‘kerosene lantern’; pididinan-gas ‘fuel-pump, valve’.
(N.) expense. pa:mangastus, pigastusan. (V.) mangastus ‘spend, expend’. pa:ngastus, a:gastus/a:gasta, makigastusan, gastusan.
(N.) milk. maggagatas ‘milk vendor’. (V.) pakigatas, pa:gatas, pa:ngatasan, gatasan ‘milk an animal’, ge:tasan. (D.) magatas ‘lactating’. megatas, makagatas.
(V.) gawaq, gagawan, ma:ngawaq; ginawaq, gewa, mengawaq; gumawaq, gawan, mangawaq; makagawaq; pa:gawaq; igawaq ‘make something for someone’.
(N./St.) habit, custom. pekagawiq. (D.) magawiq, megawiq; makagawiq ‘habit-forming’ (V.) a:gawiq, a:gawyan, mipagawiq.

(V.) decorate; dress up fancily. gagayak, igayak (Ben.), maggayak, makigayak, maka:gayak, pa:gayak, a:gayak, pa:ngayak, mangayak. (N.) kagayak ‘one decorated the same’, pa:mangayak. (D.) makagaya’k ‘be dressed fancily’, ka:gayak ‘very fancily decorated’, pe:kagayak.
(N.) a net used in fishponds for catching the smaller atiran.
(V.) gegege ‘speak in a certain manner said to be characteristic of those living along the river’.
(N.) war. ge’ra-sivi’l ‘civil war, family or marital spat’.
(V.) chew, break seeds open with teeth. manggigut.
(N.) slice. (V.) gigiliq, gilyan, igiliq, ma:ngiliq, maka:giliq, pa:giliq, pa:ngiliq, a:giliq, ke:giliq.
(N.) edge, brim, brink, side; see tagilid. (V.) mangilid ‘be on the brink, almost overflowing’, mangilid-lwaq ‘be on the brink of tears’, managilid ‘have diarrhea’.
(V.) ma:nggiligit ‘trembling internally, tense with anger’. pa:nggiligita’n.
(N.) sir, master (a title of respect given to males); boss. pa:manginu, Apung Ginu ‘the Lord (Jesus Christ)’.
(N.) a carpenter’s tool, made of wood and used for marking thicknesses.
(N.) faucet; spout on a pump; artesian well.
(St./D.) used up, consumed. megisan, makagisan. (V.) gisan, ginisan, gisanan, mangagisan, pa:gisan, a:gisan, ke:gisan.
(D./St.) megiting ‘strangled, marked or circulation cut off by a tight bind’.
(N.) starch; shampoo; see gugu; a kind of tree.
(N.) rubber; things made of rubber as tires, rubber bands.

(N.) a kind of caroling–the singing of religious songs on the eve of religious/secular feasts such as All Saints Day and the barrio fiesta.  (V.) manggosu, maggosu, makipangosu, makapanggosu, papaggosu, papaggosuwan, a:goswan.
(N.) forest; overgrown fields. gubatan ‘forest, deep-mud fields’. (D.) magubat.
(N.) a large tree, the bark of which is used for shampoo; see gogo.
(N.) line, stripe. (V.) manggulis, maka:gulis, makigulis, pakigulis, igulis, a:gulis, migulisan, pa:ngulisan, gulisan, ginulis ‘planned, blueprinted, diagramed. (D.) magulis, megulis, makagulis.
(V.) shout. gugulisak, ginulisak, makagulisak, mangulisak, gulisakan, gilisakan, igulisak, a:gulisak, pa:gulisakan, a:gulisakan, pa:ngulisakan.
(N.) trouble, disturbance. (V.) mangulu. (D.) magulu ‘troublesome, disturbing, disturbed, in disarray’.
(N.) a preventative measure (magical) taken, e.g. as one is about to fight.
(N.) back (person, hand, house). kagulutan, pa:manggulut. (D./St.) makagulut ‘with back turned’.
(N.) scissors. (V.) mangunting, igunting, pakigunting, makigunting, a:gunting, pa:gunting, pa:nguntingan, ke:gunting, mangagunting, guntingan, gintingan. (D.) mangunting, megunting, makagunting.
(N.) guramy, a kind of fish, thought locally to be Japanese in origin but actually introduced from Java by the Americans; a war-time script issued by the Japanese government.
(N.) a kind of skin eruption, said to be caused by dirt. (V.) ma:ngutliq, mangagutlian, ke:gutliq. (D.) magutliq, makagutliq, megutlian.
(N.) a kind of rope; craving. (V.) guyuran ‘drag something’.
(N.) gloves (sometimes socks with holes made for the fingers–used during harvesting).
(N.) railing (of stairs). (V.) manguyebnan (e.g. children line up in size like stairs).
(N.) a green-skinned, oval-shaped fruit with spines, has seeds and a sour-sweet taste.
(D./St.) satisfied, full (of food). (V.) magpakabsiq, mangabsiq, mabsiq, pakakabsiq, pekakabsiq, kasingkabsiq.
(N.) lawyer, attorney. (V.) magqabugadu ‘study law; debate, engage in competitive conversation’; pagqabugadwan ‘submit something to lawyers’.
(N.) Christmas present. pangqaginaldu. (V.) makayaginaldu, makiqaginaldu, a:yaginaldu. (D.) maqaginaldu, mikayaginaldu.
(N.) noise. (V.) make noise. manqalburutu, magqalburutu, mapagqalburutu, pa:nalburutwan.
(V.) rent space, hire a vehicle. manqarkila, mangayarkila, makayarkila, pakiqarkila, makipayarkila, arkilan, iqarkila, meyarkila.
(D./St.) dizzy. maqibe, meqibe, maqiqibe, mayiqibe, makaqibe.
(D.) maqibug ‘have a taste for, be eager to…’.
(D./St.) have a taste for, be fond of. maqilig, makiqilig.
(D./St.) thin. maqimpis, meqimpis, kayimpis. (V.) impisan ‘make something thin’; mipayimpis ‘made too (very) thin’.
(V.) minaq, miminaq ‘grow weak’. (D.) maqinaq, mainaq ‘be weak’.

(N./V.) drink. (N.) inuman ‘place to drink; thing to drink’. pa:maninum/pa:manqinum; i:num ‘thing drunk’. (V.) minum, miminum, ininum/qinqinum, a:yinum, na:nqinum, pa:qinuman, pa:ninum. (D.) maqinum ‘potable’. meqinum, makiqinuman; makaqinum ‘drunk’; miqinum.
(V.) beware, take care. mimingat, miningat, ma:ningat; ingatan, iningat.
(V.) think. mi:sip, minisip, makiqisip, pakiqisip, isipan, inisip; pa:qisip, a:yisip; pa:misipanan. (D.) maqisip ‘thoughtful’. pekamayisip, kasingqisip.
(V.) annual or bi-annual scrubbing of houses. ma:nisis, pa:yisis, a:yisis, pakiqisis, makiqisis. (D.) maqisis, meqisis, makaqisis. (N.) pa:manisis/pa:manqisis, pekaqisis.
(N.) history; story. (V.) magqistorya ‘tell a story’; manqistorya; qistoryan ‘tell about something’; makiqistorya. (D.) maqistorya ‘talkative’.
(V.) wash (dishes, feet). manos, menos, pakiqos, pa:qos, a:qos, pa:nwasan, inoqos, makaqos. (N.) pa:manqos.
(N.) hospital. (V./St.) inqospital, meqospital, maqospital, makaqospital, pa:qospital, mangaqospital.
(V.) climb, ascend. mukyat, manqukyat, pa:qukyat, a:yukyat, iqukyat, pakiqukyat, pa:nukyatan, pa:ukyatan, miyukyat. (N.) pa:manukyat. (D.) maqukyat, mequkyat, makaqukyat.
(V.) hair-cut. ma:nqurud, inqurud, pa:qurud, ururan, pa:qururan.
(N./V.) origin, source; come from. (Prep.) ibat ‘starting from’. (N.) ibatan, pibatan. (V.) manibatan, menibatan, pa:nibatan; kaibatibat ‘just came from’. (Q.) kaibat ‘afterwards, then’.
(V.) give. ibie, (i)babye, binye, bibye; mye, munye, makaibye, makibyebye, a:ibye, pa:ibye, mipabye, pamamye, pemamye, pamye, pemye, pakibye.
(N.) father (somewhat formal). Ibpa Mi ‘Our Father (Lord’s prayer)’.
(D.) maibug ‘be accustomed to something, have a taste for something’.
(V.) go up; enter (go up the ladder) a house. manik, menik, ipanik, a:panik, makapanik, pa:manik, pa:panik, pa:panikan ‘the-going-up’ (a stage in courtship).
(Subs.) we (not address); alternates with ike; short form: kami/ke.
(V.) braid. mikat, mimikat, minikat, makaikat, pakiikat, pa:yikat, a:yikat, mipanikat, ikatan, inikat, pa:nikatan. (N.) pa:manikat ‘braiding’.

(V.) igpitan ‘tighten something’. manigpit, mangaigpit, makiigpit, pa:igpit, a:igpit, ke:igpit, maipanigpit, kayigpitan. (N.) pa:manigpit; igpitan ‘a special enclosure in fishponds (stage after the biyayan nursery)’. (D.) maigpit, meigpit, makaigpit, kasingigpit, pekamaigpit.
(N.) a round woven basket, 2-3 inches in depth, used in winnowing rice. Tagalog bila-o.
See qili ‘laugh’. mayli, makakayli, pakailyan, ke:ilyan, mipakaili, makaili, makapakaili, maili, meili. (N.) pa:mangayili’.
(N.) roofs of cogon grass [seen on a trip to Olongapo]; see talahib/talayib.
(D.) mailig ‘have a taste for, be interested in’. makailig, mikiilig, kailigan, pekamakailig.
(N.) a curer (specialist in massage, sprains, bone setting). (V.) ilutan ‘have something treated by a hilut’.
(V.) wash face. manimuq, makapanimuq, imuwan, inimuq, pakiimwan, panimwan, a:yimuq. (D.) maimuq ‘(face)washed’, meimuq, makaqimuq.
(N.) injection, innoculations. [some speakers say: ileksyun/paileksyun, ileksyunan].
(N.) one who tends a horse or carabao; jockey. (V.) magqinete.
(V.) dream; see -ninap. (D.) mainip ‘lonely, daydreaming; absent-minded’. makainip, pekamainip, ke:inip.
(V.) understand. manatindi, menatindi, makapaintindi, panatindi, mipanatindi, a:intindian, pa:intindi. (N.) pa:manatindi.
See qinu’m ‘drink’. (N.) inuman ‘drink’; pinuman ‘drinking jar’. (V.) minum ‘drink’.
(CMP) singular, marks topic or emphasized noun phrase.
See qi’ngat ‘beware, watch out for’. (N.) ingat-bandi ‘treasurer’. (V.) ingatan, ipakiqingat.
(N.) discuss something to straighten out a problem; see tulid.

See qi’sip ‘think’. misip, manisip, menisip, makiqisip, pakiqisip, a:isip, pa:yisip, mipanisip, pa:misipan, isipan. (N.) pa:manisip; kaisip ‘one who thinks the same’; pa:misip ‘mind’; kaisipan. (D.) maisip, meisip, makaisip, pekamaisip.
(N.) one of the suits of cards in the game of monte.
(N.) a treat, delicacy, such as candy–a rather dry sort of cookie-like pastry.

(N.) stake, as bamboo stakes around a plant to protect it; nipa branches lined up in a fishpond to prevent lumot from being disturbed by wind. pa:manistaka. ( V.) manistaka, pa:istaka, istakan, inistaka/ inistakan, makapanistaka, pakiistaka, makiistaka, a:istakan, miistakan. (D.) maistaka, meistaka, makaistaka.
(N.) thigh; the place where legs join trunk.
(N.) appearance. deqitcura. (V.) pa:itcura, pakiitcuran, itcuran ‘recognize someone’, initcuran, pa:nitcuran, ayitcuran. (D.) makiitcura; (matcura ‘ugly’)?.
(N.) son [generally a term of address used by an adult to a boy, not necessarily his own son].
(V.) wash clothes, do laundry. maglaba, makapaglabada, pa:labada.

(V.) oppose, compete, fight against. laban-asbuk ‘argue’; lalabanan, le:banan, makilaban, pakipaglaban, pa:labanan, a:kalaban, pilalaban. (N.) kalaban ‘opponent’. milalaban, akalaban, pakalaban ‘thing go oppose with’, pa:laban ‘the fight promoter’.
(V.) pass by, pass through (in the process of leaving, going out).
(N.) lip(s). (V.) lalabian ‘stick lip out at someone’. (D.) malabiq ‘having big lips’; kalabiq.
(N.) excess, what is left-over, survivor. labing-metung ‘elevent’; labing-aduaq ‘twelve’; labing-atlu ‘thirteen’; [etc.]. (V.) labinan ‘survive something’.
(V.) lalabit ‘blabber, chatter without stopping’. maglabit. (D.) malabit ‘talkative’.
(D.) malablab ‘get big, swell up (of flames, of the surface of a fishpond)’.
(V.) blow air into something. labulan, lalabulan, le:bulan.
(N.) earth. tibuan-labuad ‘native land’; mabilug a labwad ‘the whole earth’; taung labuad ‘a native’.
(V.) walk. lalakad; pa:lakaran ‘send on an errand’. (N.) gait, pace; course. lakad ning panaun, pa:maglakad.
(N.) a woven rattan ring for supporting round-bottomed pots on flat surfaces.
(N.) glutinous rice; white corn; a kind of banana.
(V.) devour, eat like a pig. laklakan, lalaklakan, liklak.

(V.) remove, delete, detach, eject, send away. ilako ‘remove something’; le:ko, lakwan ‘leave someone’; likwan, milako, milako a male-tau ‘fainted’; pakilako, pa:lakwan. (N.) pa:kalako ‘instrument to remove’.
(V.) spread out, display. iladlad ‘spread something out’; laladlad.
(N.) scythe, a curbed bolo used in cutting palay. kalait ‘hook’.
(N.) carpenter’s saw. (V.) maglaragiq ‘saw’. lagari(an) ‘saw (something specific)’, le:gariq. (D.) malagariq, melagariq.
(N.) one who easily sees (is in communication with?) spirits. [This communication/apparition is said to take place most often on rainy Friday afternoons]; see lage, maglalage.

(V.) appear, come out, bring out or put on (a performance). lage, lalage, ipalage ‘relax’; pa:lage ‘opinion’; milage ‘appeared, presented, served’. (N.) maglalage ‘spirit(s), apparition; see lagayan. pa:maglage ‘appearance’.
(N.) a creaking noise, sound. (V.) maglagitik, lalagitik.
(V./D.) loose, falling off, parting company. lalaglag, ipalaglag, malaglag.
(N.) fever. (D.) malagnat, mangalagnat. (V.) ke:lagnat, lagnat, lalagnat, linagnat.
(N.) beauty. (D.) malaguq, kalaguq, melaguq. (V.) lalaguq, la:guq.

(D.) malagwaq ‘fast, swift, quick’. (V.) lalagwaq ‘do something fast’. ma:malagwa’q; pa:lagwanan; pa:malagwanan ‘expedite something’; malagwat-salitaq ‘in short, in a few words, to made a long story short’.
(N.) name. kalagyuq ‘one with the same name as another’. (V.) pa:lagyuq, a:palagyuq, pa:lagwan (?palagyuwan), pa:malagwan, pa:malagyuq.
(V.) maglala ‘weave’. lalan ‘weave into something’; lalandase ‘woven mats’.
(N.) male, man, (pl.) la:laki. (V.) magpakalalaki ‘act like a man’.
(N.) the underneath-area; depth; (speech) old, fancy, obscure. (D.) malalam ‘deep, below’ malalam, pekamalalam ‘deepest’; mipalalam ‘been put under’.
(St./D./N.) excess. pangalalu ‘envy, jealousy’; mangalalu ‘be envious; milalalu; mapangalalu; lalung marok ‘worse’; lalung marayuq ‘farther’.
(N./D.) name of a bus line; a family name; kind of watermelon [yellow-orange melon and buses].
(N.) contents; fleshy. kalamnan ‘contents, table of’. (D.) malaman.
(N.) affection. (D.) malambing, melambing, malambing a musika ‘flowing music’.
(V.) offer condolences, attend a wake. maglame, makipaglame.
(D.) malanam ‘smell or quality of rotting fish’.
(D.) a quality of fruits. [opposite of malambut, mibawiq].

(V./St.) be in heat. maglandiq, makapaglandiq, makilandiq, paglandian, pakilandian, ke:landian, a:landiq. (D.) malandiq, melandiq, pekamalandiq. (N.) kalandian ‘(promiscuity?), the fact of being in heat’, pipaglandian.
(V.) get dry, dry something. lalangiq, pa:langian, a:palangiq. (D.) malangiq ‘dry’.
(D.) exact, fit, adjusted. (V.) ilapat ‘adjust something’. (N.) pangalapat.
(V.) pinch (a small amount of skin). lepirut.
(V.) lapitan ‘draw near to something’. linapit, lumapit, milapitan, a:lapit, a:kalapit. (D.) malapit ‘near, adjacent’. kalapit.
(V.) overflow. lalapo, linapu, lumapu, maglapu, mangalapu, pa:lapawan, a:palapo.
(V.) proceed, let…loose. linarga ‘let loose, given slack’.
(N.) oil (usually from coconuts, used formerly–now, by old women– as a hair dressing); also applies to vegetable oils, motor oil.
(V.) lasakan ‘destroy something’. lesakan, maglasak, makapaglasak, mangalasak, pakilasak, pa:lasak, a:lasak, pa:nlasak, ke:lasak. (D.) malasak ‘torn down’.
(V.) lasawan ‘digest something’. (D.) malaso ‘digestable, dissolved’. maglasu-anak ‘have an abortion (miscarriage?); pa:lasu, makalasu, pa:nlaswan, pa:nlasu, a:laso, ke:laso. (N.) pa:manlaso.
(N.) ribbon; also some sort of mouth sore.
(N.) poison. pa:maglasun. (V.) lasunan ‘poison someone/thing’; le:sunan, maglasun, makapaglasun, makilasun, pakilasun, pa:lasun, a:lasun, ke:lasun, mangalasun, pinlasun. (D.) malasun, melasun.
(N.) tin can. tukong lata ‘e.g. square kerosene can’; barungganan-lata ‘kick-the-can (a children’s game)’.
(D.) malatiq ‘small’. (V.) lalatiq ‘grow small’; ilatiq ‘make something smaller’; magmalatiq, magpalatiq, pa:latian, mipalatiq. (N.) kalatian.
(N.) a sauce of sugar and toasted coconut. (D.) malatik ‘a phase of the moon when it is small’.
(D.) old, worn out; dehydrated, dessicated. laun-ayabyas. la’us/la’wus (V.) proceed, continue. malaus, melaus ‘old, useless’.
(V.) look at; see lon, lalon, lawen. maglawe, lalawe, linawe, lumawe, pa:lawe, lawan ‘look at something’, lawen, lawenlawen, lon, lalon, pakilon.
(N.) a Christmas-eve celebration (in Candaba)–singing between two groups who represent the Holy Family and the people of Bethlehem.
(N.) league, a measure of distance. [usually restricted to story-telling].
(N.) a chicken-and-rice stew or porridge; see lulut.
(D.) malibatu ‘a stage in the maturity of mangos (between manibala’ng and malu’tu)’.
(N.) portion or a rice field; see lubluban.
(V.) lilibut ‘go around’. lumibut, maglibut, makalibut, pa:libut, a:libut, pa:nlibutan.
(St.) center, centered. libutad ‘put something in center’; makalibutad. (N.) kalibutdan.
(V.) remove contents from one place and put in another, transfer, translate; see lukas. lilikas, linikas, ilikas, pa:likas. (N.) talapaglikas ‘interpreter’.
(D.) maliku’t ‘overactive, always moving, restless, fidgety (usually of children–in Filipino English the child is said to be “moveable”)’.
(D.) maligatligat ‘soft, sticky; smooth texture’. kaligatan ‘just right’.
(V.) magligpit ‘arrange, straighten, fix, put in order’.
(N.) sack, burlap bag. (V.) ilinggotci, pa:linggotci, makilinggotci, pakilinggotci. (D./St.) makalinggotci.
(N.) week; see duminggu. pa:ruminggu ‘one week’; peparuminggu.
(N.) staple, something used to fasten corrugated iron roofing.
(V.) move, transfer, change places. maglipat, ilipat, linipat, palipatan, makilipat, pakilipat, palipatlipat, milipat. (N.) pipaglipatan, pilipatan.
(V.) push up, roll up (sleeves, pants). lilislis, pa:lislis, a:lislis, maglislis, mangalislis. (D.) malislis, melislis, makalislis.
(N.) tendon, cartilage. lilitid. (V.) litiran ‘cut the tendon’.
(N.) a liquid measure used with gasoline and kerosene; a dry measure used with palay, also the box used to measure palay. [six litru = one patiq].
(N.) a kind of fish, noted for its spines. (D.) maliwaluq, Maliualu ‘a barrio of Bacolor famous for a massacre which took place there in the early 1950s’.
(D.) maliwanag ‘bright, shining’. [sometimes used with kwalta ‘money’ to mean “jackpot”].
(V.) take someone’s place; pass going in opposite directions and fail to meet. miliwas.
(Subs.) (portmanteau) na + la; limited to occurrences with atin, alaq.
(D./St.) crazy; also loka for females. (V.) lokwan ‘fool, tease someone’. pa:loku, a:loku, magloku.
(V.) lololo ‘hang down long (a dog’s tongue, a dress)’. nilolo.
(N.) lot, plot of land, subdivision. lotiloti ‘subdivision’.
(N.) inside, the interior of something; one’s soul, mind, feelings, sentiment, etc. work–something to go in to do. kaluban ‘holster, sheath’. (V.) lulub, lungub, ilub, pa:luban pakilub.
(D.) malub, makalub. (V.) lubakan ‘loosen something’. (D.) malubak ‘be loose’.
(N.) one square of rice fields; see libluban.
(N.) the catching pond in a fishpond system.
(N.) eating until satisfied, the manner of such eating.
(V.) take off (clothes). lukas, likas, maglukas, paglukas, pa:lukas, a:lukas, ilukas. (N.) lukas-paldas ‘the removing of ceremonial black (clothes or ribbon) one year after a family death’.
(V.) sit, take a seat. (N.) luklukan ‘seat, place to sit. pa:maglukluk ‘sitting’. (D./St.) makalukluk ‘seated’.
(V.) roll things up. maglukut, pakilukut, pa:lukut, a:lukut. (D.) malukut, melukut, makalukut.
(N.) place, location, space. (V.) ilugal ‘give place to someone’. milugal.
(N.) love. kalugudlugud ‘dear ones’; ka:luguran ‘beloved, sweetheart’; kaluguran ‘friend’, (pl.) kakaluguran. (V.) kaluguran ‘love someone’. makikaluguran, mikaluguran. (D.) malugud ‘dear’.
(N.) clouds, overcast; see lulam. (D.) malulaq ‘cloudy, overcast’. (V.) maglulaq ‘be about to rain’.
(V.) break through, pierce, burst through, bloom. lulsut, linsut, mangalsut, makalsut.
(N.) pity, mercy. kalulu ‘poor man’; pakalulu ‘have mercy, pity someone’.
(V.) squeeze into an opening in a line; win a narrow election.
(N.) that part of a plow which pushes the turned up dirt away from the blade.
(N.) Monday. (D.) malulunis, melunis, mangalunis ‘have bad luck on Monday and spoil the whole week’.
(N.) face. kalupa ‘look like (one with same face as another)’; milupa ‘similar, same’.
(N.) outside. (V.) go out. luwal, lumuwal, linuwal, ilual ‘take something out’, pa:luwalan, miluwal.
(D.) second, two days from…; see adwaq.
(Q.) how, in what manner. Makananu reng gamitan? ‘How are those used?’.
(N.) profit. (V.) go to Holy Communion. (N.) pamakinabang ‘Holy Communion’.

(N.) macopa, a kind of fruit, grows on trees, is red and bell-shaped, roughly apricot sized, similar to what is called mountain apple in Hawaii. There are two types: makupang kapampangan, makupang malutu.
(N.) a tree-like plant, with many trunks, used for firewood and leaves fed to goats.
(N.) corn. mais lakatan ‘white corn’; mais malutu ‘yellow corn’; maisan ‘cornfield’; busang mais ‘popcorn’; ligang mais ‘boiled corn’; swam mais ‘a dish of mixed vegetables including corn’.
(N.) the common man, everyone, populace. ding maldaq ‘all the people’; babasan maldaq ‘popular reader’.
(N.) consciousness; occurs in the phrase: milako a male-tau ‘fainted’.
(N.) error, mistake. (V.) magkamaliq ‘err, make a mistake’.
(N.) Maliualu–a barrio of Bacolor, famous for a massacre in the early 1950s.
(N.) mister, a term of address used to men (polite)–not used with names as English Mr.
(V.) come in; you are welcome. [a rare, “deep” word].
(V.) searching for; in the metaphorical sentence Manalanga: yang pugad ‘He is looking for a nest’ i.e. ‘is courting a girl’.
(V.) stop, stay, be with; occurs in the religious phrase: Ing Ginu manatili ya kekayu. ‘God be with you’.
(V.) waiting for someone, something; see panayan.
(V.) magmaneu ‘drive (a vehicle) – usually meaning to drive for pay’.
(V.) go upstairs. cf. qik ma:manikan, me:nik. (N.) pa:manikan ‘a stage in courtship when the boy is invited to visit the girl in her house’.
(V.) have or express strong feelings for another; panigapuq.
(V./D.?) eat something which tastes sour, as a citrus or santol. menisig
(N.) a small fruit-like object which grows on trees [debatable whether or not it is eaten] used to refer to olives (perhaps mistakenly).
(V.) ask for; inyad. cf. anyad, anyawad.
(Q.) used with dates, times, other numbers, to mean approximately.
(V.) save, redeem, pardon [used in religious texts].
(D.) sting (e.g. a wound, when medicine is applied).
[lit. mark of the devil] = gin, esp. San Miguel brand gin, which has a picture of Michael slaying Lucifer on the bottle.
(N.) a special type of rice or manner of spaced planting recently introduced by agricultural agents.
(N.) a female name–Maria. atlung mariya ‘name of a constellation’.
(Q.) [used in comparative constructions] Mas matas ka kaku ‘You are taller than I’; Mas masanting ya ita kesa kanita ‘That is nicer than that other one’.
(N.) a system of planting rice by carefully measuring the distance between plantings.
(N.) chewing tobacco; also included in the betel chew and in cigarettes of the roll-your-own variety.
(Q./Subcomb.) even though. [used as a complete utterance: Never mind, ignore it, so what].
(V.) look after, watch for, look for, pagmasdan, pigmasdan.
(Q.) very, too much. Generally used as Q. to a D. E masyadung mabayat ‘Not very heavy’.
(N.) eye; shoot, sprout, as: mata kwayan; the spots on the top half of a coconut shell (bikan lalaki) are mata. telataung mata ‘iris (of the eye)’.
(V.)  hire others to harvest. mamatas, makipamatas.
(V.) die; me:te, ikamate, makamate; see pate, paten. (N.) kamatayan ‘death’.
(N.) a small bird, the rice bird. putu-maya ‘a rice-cake delicacy made of sugar, coconut, and glutinous rice’.
(D.) sweet. (N.) sugar, candy, sweets. pagmayumu ‘preservative for fruits’.
(N.) cough medicine (from the brand name Medicol).
(D.) crazy, lacking mentally. minus ‘e.g. with numbers’; menus singko ‘subtract five’; menus-gastus ‘thrifty, cutting down on expenses’. makamenus
(N.) 1. meter (a measure of length, distance). 2. a carpenter’s rule; see medida.
(V.) [special] happened, as in: Nanung milyari? ‘What happened?’.
(N.) mine; mined substance, mineral. Kalburu, klasing mina yan, e. ‘Carbide, that is a type of mined substance/mineral’.
(N.) river flood control, dike, bank. (V.) magminangun, minangunan, pami-nangun, makiminangun.
(N.) miss, a term of address to an unmarried female.
(N.) mass, a Catholic ceremony. (V.) pa:misa ‘have a mass said’.
(Q./N.?) once in a while (a time measure). pamisanmisan.
(N.) 1. a term of address for married women, Mrs. Kumusta, misis? ‘How are you, ma’m?’.
(V./St./D.) burst (a blister or boil); blinking (as, lights which go on and off).
(N.) a gambling game played with cards.
(V.) (St./N./D.?) be angry. mimimwaq, mimwaq, me:muaq, ikamuaq.
(V.) open a dam, splurge with savings.
(N.) yard, the area surrounding a house.
(V.) pagmulala’n ‘to stay without consent in someone’s house’.
(V./D./St.) be surprised. mipamulalaq, mangapamlalaq, makapag-mulalaq; magmulalaq ‘stand gaping, act or look like an “innocente” (booby)’.
(D.) crazy, foolish, rabid. (V.) magmulang ‘(of an engine, not working properly)’. (N.) kamulangan ‘foolishness’.
(V.) go home; see uliq. [Bacolor informants say that in the Sta. Rita dialect this means to go marketing].
(V.) [root? putut, butut?] ‘nibble at food, eat timidly or uneagerly’.
(V./St.) mamunagmunag ‘(sun) is rising, (person) arise with the sun’.
(N.) earth, world. kamundwan ‘earthly concerns, worldly things, mundane matters’.
(N.) Moros, Muslims. (V.) magmurusmurus ‘be a “pagan”, act like a “Moro”’.
